The street level bar was great for late night snack and chaser. The hotel could better highlight the old photos of the Oscar ceremonies held there and the hotel connection with the Black Dahlia mystery . One unexplainable was the tremendous noise of moving furniture we experienced above us between approx. 2-4 in the morning, at times ebbing then giving to violent throws. We inquired at checkout after learning my brother in a different corridor heard the same thing, and the hotel staff checked the bookings and the floor above us was entirely vacant they insisted, with only one elderly couple in their 80's on the 10th floor that was on file.

Reviews.Title: “Faded Glory”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: The Biltmore is a stunningly beautiful hotel. Built in the early 1920's, the decor and construction of the common areas reflect the opulence of the period and show an incredible attention to detail. The service is very good. If a bit more attention were paid to the maintenance of the rooms, it would make for an wonderful experience. My wife and I stayed at the Biltmore for Valentine's day weekend. Although we live in Los Angeles, I thought it would be a nice treat. Overall, we weren't disappointed. We really enjoyed our stay. We paid $169 per night for two nights in a king room on the Club Level. I thought it was a good bargain. Had the suites been more reasonably priced, I might have opted for that, but they wanted somewhere in the neighborhood of $450 per night, so I passed. Common Areas: Most of the common areas in the Biltmore are breathtaking. We entered through the Rendezvous Court, then up the staircase, past the elevators, through the Concourse, and into the Lobby to check in. I had been in the Biltmore before, but each of these areas had my wife looking around in wonder. The bar, ballroom, and other meeting rooms are also elegant and worth a look. The Club Level lounge was great. Although we weren't able to make it for the afternoon hors d'oeuvre, the breakfast was nice. Eggs, potatoes, pastries, fruit bowls, and parfaits. The decor was elegant and pleasant, with a good view of the city. The only common area I would say I was disappointed with was the pool, not because it wasn't nice, but because of the wasted potential. The pool itself is incredible. Great Neptune themed tilework, brass (I assume) railings surrounding the pool and the brass around the windows, the columns; it's a fantastic room. Unfortunately, they decided to put all the workout equipment in the areas surrounding the pool. It's all visible through the windows. It completely shatters the illusion. If the windows were mirrored, or the equipment were in some other way hidden from view, being in that pool room would be like being transported into the Great Gatsby. It's an opportunity for a unique experience that, unfortunately, isn't realized. The room: The room reminded me of staying in my 90 year old great aunt's house. Everything was quality, but old, which isn't necessarily bad, but lacked attention. We had a king room. The bed was comfortable. The furniture was faux antiques. Not anything amazing, but certainly much better than standard hotel furniture, and it was in keeping with the overall decor. The bathroom had nice period fixtures and was pleasant and adequate. The big problem with the room was the lack of maintenance. It wasn't horrible, but it could have been much better. The main problem was the dust. As another commenter wrote, the canopy over the bed and the curtains are both dust magnets, and should be cleaned frequently. I'm sure this isn't happening. On our last morning, I looked above the canopy and saw at least a couple of months worth of dust collected up there. While it didn't bother me terribly, my wife is allergic, and it really annoyed her. She could tell it was dusty, and we ended up sleeping with our heads at the foot of the bed. There are other maintenance issues as well. The curtains had tears on both sides at the point where the rod ends, no doubt due to years of friction. They need to be replaced. There was also a crack in the paint above the molding. It wouldn't take much to fix it. If these issues were sorted out it would bump up the Biltmore experience tremendously. Service: The service was good. The woman who took my original reservation over the phone was very pleasant and helpful. Check-in and check-out were fine. Someone dropped the ball on one request I had, though. I had asked for down free bedding when I reserved, and reconfirmed this a couple of days before check-in. It wasn't done. A phone call to room service and someone was up within ten minutes, but it should have been done right from the start. One thing I was impressed with: the hostess at the lounge asked me how I was enjoying my stay. When I mentioned about the dust, she immediately asked my room number and was going to send someone to clean. Unfortunately, we were checking out within a couple of hours, so it didn't help me, but the attitude was great. It should have occurred to me to call and have the dust cleaned earlier. I'm sure they would have taken care of it. Overall: Again, stunning common areas. Good service. Reasonable rates. More attention to details in the rooms would make the Biltmore a unique and unforgettable experience.

Reviews.Title: “Classic and Quiet”
Reviews.Author: mandieree
Reviews.Content: This hotel exudes classic elegance, the lobby area is lovely and the bar is classic and sophisticated. The guest rooms are spacious, however, the bathroom is tiny and unimpressive. The rooms include slippers and a robe, a nice touch, but a mini fridge would have been appreciated more. The parking was expensive, but not more unreasonable than most downtown hotels. The staff was friendly and addressed up courteously, but was not very expedient with our check-in nor was the valet quick at processing our ticket and bringing the car around. Despite minor inconveniences, we were happy with the hotel. We especially appreciated the century old construction, the walls must have been better insulated back then, because it was absolutely silent at night, even with a wedding downstairs. We had a great night's sleep!

Reviews.Title: “Atmosphere and comfort”
Reviews.Author: Sutter
Reviews.Content: We stayed one night shortly after Christmas, largely in order to be close to Union Station for a morning Amtrak departure. When we checked in, we mentioned we wanted a room with a safe and, if possible, on an upper floor, for quiet. We were given a club level room on the penultimate floor. I paid about $160 for a standard room (AARP rate), but with the free upgrade the room was a very good deal. We had a view of Pershing Square, which was packed with ice skaters and those watching free music performances. The hotel has a lot of historic atmosphere and one can easily imagine Hollywood stars of the 30s and 40s staying there (the Academy Awards took place in the hotel for a short time-- in the Biltmore Bowl, which burned down). A few people said the largest photo in the corridor reminded them of a scene in "The Shining." A few wedding receptions were going on but did not bother us. We did not have dinner in the hotel, partly due to prices, but had a drink in the lovely bar ($15 for a gin martini is a bit outrageous, however). We walked around the area quite a bit and felt safe (front desk said it would be). Particularly enjoyed visiting the historic Bradbury Building (site of many films), Grand Central Market (lots of places to eat there), and Angels Flight vernicular (unfortunately, closed for maintenance). The hotel is within short walking distance of a Red Line subway station, which we used to get to Union Station.

Reviews.Title: “Downtown Gem”
Reviews.Author: Seemonkey
Reviews.Content: Okay, so this hotel is downtown, which as you may already know isn't a necessity as its a bit run down. If you do visit, stay here. Note: this part of downtown is the business district, so there isnt much to do. The interior is beautiful, with immense decor. rooms are small, but better than average in quality. Tips: Valet parking is $40, literally across the road is a self park, maximum daily charge $12 with overnight at $5. ( but there are many other parking facilites nearby) If your not driving get off at Pershing Square its across the road from the hotel, Visit the gym/ pool, although in the basement, its beautifully decorated. Nearby there are various diners etc.

Reviews.Title: “Majestic, Grand, Old, and Refreshing”
Reviews.Author: lgjdf'gjdg
Reviews.Content: Let me preface this review with the fact that I am a very fussy person, and know what I want. When I travel, I always request a corner room on a top floor. In addition, if a concierge or club level is available, this is what I reserve. We traveled to Los Angeles for our son's wedding on New Year's Eve. The bride had blocked rooms at the Kyoto Grand, however gave several other choices including the Millennium Biltmore, Westin Bonaventure, and Standard. We chose the Biltmore for nostalgic reasons given its history and are happy that we did. Upon entering the lobby, one can not help but get caught up in the opulence of the lobby, ballroom, and Gallery Bar. We so enjoyed taking a trip down "memory lane" while viewing all the old photographs of past movie stars and Academy Award celebrations. I had requested the club level (concierge level) when booking this hotel. Upon checking in, we were told that the club lounge was closed and we would receive vouchers for drinks and breakfast. I had asked for a large corner room with a rollaway, as our younger son was joining us. I was told that this should not be a problem in terms of size, however, it was. Thank goodness for Jose, the bellman. He showed us approximately five rooms on this level, none of which was ample size. With that, he phoned the front desk and informed Greg of our dilemma suggesting that maybe they could give us a junior suite. Greg was most accommodating, and did just that at no extra cost. In fact, they didn't even charge us for the rollaway! Although the suite was not on the club level, we still received club level amenities (cocktails, and full buffet breakfast which would have been continental had the lounge been open). The room was not renovated as were the ones on the club level floors, but it was very large and clean and housekeeping was most accommodating. I can not say enough about the staff at this "Grand Lady". From the parking valets, to the doormen, to the front desk staff, to the bellmen, to the housekeeping staff, waitstaff in the restaurant, and bartenders, their main goal was to make our stay as pleasant as possible, and it was! Given the circumstances, we needed to have a spacious room on this trip. However, If my husband and I we were to stay at this hotel again, we would be sure to stay in a renovated room on the club level.

Reviews.Title: “LOVED The Millennium Biltmore!”
Reviews.Author: CaramelGoodness
Reviews.Content: My boyfriend and I stayed at this hotel for 4 days before heading off to Las Vegas. Was a little worried about staying at the hotel after reading some of the negative reviews, however I was pleasantly surprised when I arrived. The hotel is amazing with a very grand feel. On other reviews people have said its old fashioned but I would say its more old style Hollywood glamour. It doesn't feel dated at all, gorgeous decor and the first floor reception and lobby are beautiful. I was shocked when we got to our room...it was HUGE and really lovely. It felt like a suite with a living area etc and a really big wardrobe. The bathroom was quite small but nice and clean. The hotel room had everything we needed, clean comfy beds, lots of info on LA, plenty of space and a big TV with lots of channels. I'm not sure if all the rooms at this hotel are the same but our room was massive. We ate at the Japanese restaurant on our first night as we was too tired to leave the building. Glad we did as it was delicious, really modern, quite pricy but definatly worth the money. Every member of staff at this hotel was lovely and helpful. Reception were extremely accommodating and couldn't do enough for you. The guy at the concierge was really helpful too. He helped us book loads of great things to do... tours etc and helped us save money whilst doing so..he also recommended good places to eat, and all that we tried were brilliant. We did a great tour of LA seeing the Hollywood houses, Chinese Theatre, Venice Beach, Santa Monica Pier, Rodeo Drive etc. Was Fab and we got to see so much of LA that on our other days we could then go back to the places we enjoyed the most. Venice beach is really nice, and has a cool vibe to the place. I love shopping and found the best shops on Melrose avenue, the shops are different and unique there and a lot cheaper than Rodeo Drive or Robertson Drive! We didn't hire a car but buses and trains are very cheap! We didn't pay a lot to stay at this hotel at all and it definatly exceeded our expectations. It is a very high standard hotel in a good location where u can feel safe at night too. I will definatly stay at this hotel again, I LOVED it!!

Reviews.Title: “Historic building with impressive lobby”
Reviews.Author: jalpnco
Reviews.Content: The lobby and ground floor of this hotel was very grand and historic. The room was small but tastefully decorated and well equipped. Like many older hotels, noise from the hallway travels easily so ask for a room away from the elevators and other busy corridors. The staff was friendly and helpful but I did have a couple of problems. I had trouble getting the internet to work($10/day) and had to leave a message for the hotel's IT person who was eventually able to help. I also had $90 of international phone calls on my bill even though I didn't make any calls. Although the front desk took the phone charges off the bill when I checked out, my credit card was charged anyway. I eventually got everything straightened out, but it was a hassle. The nearby Water Grill serves incredible seafood, but expect to pay. Lunch averaged $60/person without alcohol.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful but...”
Reviews.Author: jujusdad
Reviews.Content: Astoundingly beautiful hotel in a mundane, rather drab part of the city. If you can get a deal on a room, take it, but don't order room service or drink at the residents bar, you'll end up re-mortgaging your house. Explore the area to find better, cheaper eating/drinking options. There's a lively Irish pub down the street. My main problem was having to pay $10 a day for what was grossly substandard internet access. They call it "High Speed" but it resembled high speed in 1995. Truly dreadful but don't bother complaining, the receptionist will give you that blank look. To sum up, great to sleep in (beds are deliciously comfortable) but check out the locale, it's cheaper outside the hotel. Staff were friendly if not a little detached.

Reviews.Title: “Like a Fabulous trip back in time”
Reviews.Author: nyuszi
Reviews.Content: I thoroughly enjoyed my stay at the Biltmore and am almost tempted to give 5 stars, except for a few little niggles. To begin with the good - the ground floors are absolutely gorgeous with a great deal of restored original architecture/decor from the 1920's. My room was only a standard but quite spacious with a very comfortable bed, desk, full closet and comfy chair. My room was on the inside of the building, overlooking a quiet courtyard and I heard virtually no outside noise thanks to the white noise generated by the heat/AC. And the water pressure in the shower was fantastic. The workout equipment in the health club facilities were a little squished and I think I used the oldest still-working elliptical machine in North America. But the treadmills are all pretty new and most machines have a personal flat screen. However, that was completely made up for by the rest of the facilities - the pool, jacuzzi, sauna and spa look original and made me feel like some robber baron in the gilded age. The location is excellent for business in or near downtown and is right in the heart of the financial district. It could also be a good choice for tourists because it is so close to the 101, 110, 5 and 10 freeways, so you can pretty much get anywhere. Now for the bad things - all of which are relatively minor and would not stop me from booking here again. First, like many hotels, they charge for internet access, which I find a highly offensive practice. Also, valet is $40/night. This is not unusual in LA, but should be factored into your budget. The tub/shower had a curtain, rather than a door, which kept sticking to me because it didn't have magnets in the bottom. This was particularly gross since the housekeeping seemed hit or miss - I had 3 great days and 2 "eh" days. The TV in my room was an old, small CRT type and many of the channels buzzed or otherwise had bad reception. Finally, when I ordered room service breakfast, my receipt had the wrong name and room number on it. When I asked, the staff person told me "You must have written the wrong number on your ticket, this is for you." That was completely unacceptable at this level hotel. Even if I actually had made the mistake, I should have received "the customer is always right" treatment. But, like I said, I would definitely stay here again, it's a great hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Perfectly Fine”
Reviews.Author: tjfpa
Reviews.Content: I recently stayed there while attending a convention. As long as you can keep in mind that it is an older property you will be pleased. The bedding was fabulous and the service I received was as well. They could use some new carpets and some cosmetics but other than that I would recommend staying there. My cell phone worked great (I saw another person had a problem).

Reviews.Title: “Plushy bedding, poor cell coverage, beautiful building”
Reviews.Author: zippy47
Reviews.Content: Pros: down duvets and pillows individual thermostats power outlets at desk height wireless net works great ($10/day) Cons: non-adjustable desk chair, making the desk uncomfortable to use very bad cell coverage throughout the hotel (not their problem, but something you may need to know) expensive parking The Biltmore is a beautiful 1920's building with amazing public rooms and meeting rooms. The guest rooms vary widely: mine had an extra 150 sq. ft. of space which was devoid of furniture while other rooms felt cramped, both the result of a quirky building. Furnishings are elegant -- some might feel out of place in such surroundings. Maintenance is decent but imperfect -- expect some slight problem with the room. Some rooms face an ugly inside courtyard, but with the pretty wooden shutters, one hardly notices (even so, consider asking for an outside room). Some minor service issues, but nothing unexpected given the size of the hotel. The hotel does significant business with the consolidator AlliedTPro; if you're willing to prepay for your room, cheap rates can often be found on no-name booking sites, particularly those geared to European travelers. kayak.com was successful at finding several of those for me. Parking at the hotel is far, far more expensive than other lots nearby. Park somewhere else.

Reviews.Title: “Lots of Hollywood History here”
Reviews.Author: Sustramo
Reviews.Content: I stayed here for three nights in July while attending a meeting at the hotel. This a huge, grand, old place with an incredible history. If you go, take a look at all the photos of early Academy Award ceremonies that were held at the hotel. It's amazing. Anyway, the hotel itself is fine. The rooms are pretty basic - not too big and not too small with all the usual amenities. The bathrooms seem very outdated, though. The staff was pleasant and professional - this is a Millenium Hotel. The health club in the basement is adequate. The Japanese restaurant on-site was good, but INCREDIBLY EXPENSIVE. I think it was $180 for two of us and we each only had one drink, appetizers, and entrees!! The hotel is located in a business district, so the area gets quiet after 5:00. However, there are lots of great breakfast and lunch places (a wonderful diner around the corner) in the area. The Metro station is a block away and you can be in Hollywood in 20 minutes. I did like the hotel. With the craziness of LA, I thought it was a pleasant, quiet place to come back to at the end of the day/evening.

Reviews.Title: “IÂ´ll never be back”
Reviews.Author: Spain1978
Reviews.Content: I was at the hotel during two days on september 2008 Good Points *Location *Nice Hall and Bar Very Negative ones * The most noisy hotel IÂ´ve been on my whole life (and I use around 40 hotels/year during the last 5 years). I was at the fifth floor and a chimeny never stop making noise day and night * I requested one of the new rooms of the hotel but they didnÂ´t give it to me saying that these ones are 100$ more expensive/night. I just donÂ´t believe that itÂ´s just they didnÂ´t want to * The bathroom is extreamly old and small, ridiculous for a XXI century hotel * I was stolen a note of 100$ at the room. I left the note at my laptop bag while in the city and when I came back to the cleaned room I had been stolen As a constructive summery for readers, look for an alternative hotel at lovely LA

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful vacation!”
Reviews.Author: Karebear85
Reviews.Content: We stayed for 2 nights in a room we got a special deal on. This was a beautiful hotel, the decor and ambiance was exactly what we were hoping for. The pool and hot tub area was amazing, although we had hardly any time to relax we were so busy touring LA. The staff was friendly and helpful. We also ran into some late night filming of CSI right outside the hotel which was a great experience.

Reviews.Title: “nice hotel”
Reviews.Author: karinkSalzburg
Reviews.Content: We booked the Millenium Biltmore because we got a really good deal for one night. first impression were quite good. the looby is very impressive, staff were helpful and nice. room was okay - bit dated but massive and comfy bed which we needed after a long flight. location was so/so.. in the financial district very very quiet on weekends.

Reviews.Title: “Really Nice Hotel”
Reviews.Author: TCall07
Reviews.Content: Stayed here for 10 days in March, the hotel lobby was very impressive, staff were very helpful - the rooms were fine, seeing the lobby you get high expectations for the rooms, and while they're not exactly fancy and are maybe a little old fashioned the room was quite large and very clean. I definitely believe I got my moneys worth. Again the staff were always helpful. I especially liked the bar for a chill out drink - the music was always very cool and the bartender was great! Loved the cocktails!

Reviews.Title: “Poor Customer Service (including General Manager)”
Reviews.Author: FJW1
Reviews.Content: Simply put---the hotel lobby was nice, but the customer service was poor and I would not recomend staying here. I am an attorney and a frequent business traveler. I booked online with a friends card who wanted to pay for my hotel. When I arrived I was asked for a card for incidentals and I provided my personal card. At check out my personal card was charged and I was advised that the hotel could not charge the card that was provided during online booking. I spoke with Vincent Piro, the General Manager, and was not helpful. He explained that he has been in the hotel industry for years and they have never done that. I explained that I travel often and have never been challenged in this way. I advised him that I would not stay in this hotel again and would not recomend it to others. Further, my internet connection did not work during my entire stay. I need to work and had to leave my room and go to a Starbucks in order to work. Though cheap, this hotel is not worth the money. Please think twice before booking with them.

Reviews.Title: “$40 per day for parking!!”
Reviews.Author: ciana90Sheffield
Reviews.Content: This hotel had a really nice look to the lobby and other various rooms, although the guest rooms are very dusty and old fashioned and i dont mean the style i just mean they need modernising......ALOT! The tv looked like the oldest model iv ever seen in a hotel and the hotel itself believes its a luxury one!!! Iv never seen such old electrical appliances. Staff were friendly and it has a nice historical feel, i think thats why it gets away with being a so called luxury hotel. Its very expensive, no mini bar in the room, bathroom was tiny! I had stayed in palm springs for 3 nights before arriving here and payed $100 per night for a 5 star real luxuruy hotel and there is such a big difference in the quality of the hotels. Parking is $40 per day which is nearly more than a room itself!!! The location is good if you want to be down town LA but its far from hollywood and santa monica. If id known then what i know now there is no way id stay there and its due to overpriced parking and interenet and last but not least the location. I would much rather be on the beach or a more relaxed area.

Reviews.Title: “Loved the Biltmore”
Reviews.Author: Wongaburra
Reviews.Content: A most fascinating hotel and a delight to stay. Location, service and accommodation all excellent. Loved to be able to wander through the hotel and marvel at the ballrooms, restaurants etc. Many thanks.

Reviews.Title: “Nice lobby (and staff) but that's it!!!”
Reviews.Author: kittenmitten
Reviews.Content: Stayed here as part of honeymoon trip. Really dissappointed with room, very small, dark and somewhat depressing. The bathroom was incredibly small and both the sink and bath tub had large cracks and dirt in them. The location wasn't great, apart from access to public transport. The hotel is in the financial district so is very quiet at night. There were alot of dodgy people hanging around the Metro station and when we wondered down to the fashion and jewellery districts a police officer advised it wasn't an area for tourists and suggested we leave immediately! We ventured over to West Hollywood, which is a much nicer (and safer) area. Did eat in the Sushi restuarant within the hotel which was nice - but expensive.

Reviews.Title: “Nice hotel with history”
Reviews.Author: HongkongPeterPan
Reviews.Content: I stayed in the hotel for 3 nights with my wife during our honeymoon trip. We saw a lot of negative comments from the tripadviser. Thus, we requested a quiet room when we check in. Everything is good in the hotel room except for the old and dated bathroom. Overall, the room is clean and tidy. Our room was not facing the street so we did not have noise issue. Hotel lobby is very classic and beatiful. Photos show in the corridor towards the health centre give a very good presentation about the history of the hotel. We swan in the pool in the morning and used the hot bathing tub. It was good but the hot bathing tub was small and limited only to two people at a time. We parked our car in the underground parking of Purshing Square. It was only $15.40 for overnight (vs $42 for the hotel valvet parking). We felt safe even when we walked back to the hotel from the parking at late night. This was our first time to Los Angeles. We surely will go back to the hotel for the next visit.

Reviews.Title: “Disappointing”
Reviews.Author: onthegonewyork_ny
Reviews.Content: I recently stayed at the Biltmore with family members for a week and I was disappointed. I booked the reservation 3 months in advance. When we got to the hotel we had to wait several hours before our room was ready. The lobby area is beautiful, but the rooms are another story. The inside of the bathtub was chipped. There was a problem flushing the toilet. The television was old and small. There was a buzzing sound on some of the stations. I understand this is a old hotel but surely some upgrades can be made to the rooms without the hotel losing its historic charm. The pool area was dark and dreary. I never saw anyone there .The gift shop was over priced and some of the staff was not so friendly. I also do not consider this to be a child friendly hotel. The only good thing about this hotel is the location. It's not likely that I would stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “An elegant hotel where you can re-live history”
Reviews.Author: Londoner100
Reviews.Content: We stayed for 6 nights for around Â£50 per night via 0800 hotels.co.uk. This proved excellent value. As mentioned in other reviews the lobby is absolutely beautiful. It has a real sense of 'Hollywood history' as so many films have been shot there and in the adjoining banqueting rooms. In fact whilst we were there, there was a film shoot in progess. Front desk staff are particulalry helpful. I was unhappy with my first Single King bed room because of the buzzing from an outside aircon fan and they found me a Double Queen room immediately which was quieter. The rooms itself are not as grand as the lobby. There is also a difference in size between the single King bed room and the double queen bed rooms. The double queen bed room was much bigger whilst the single King room was a bit on the small side. The rooms are clean but I would say that most of the furniture and TV are on the old side. The bathroom was also quite dated. It seems that very little investment has been made in updating rooms in the last 10 years. Wireless internet was expensive at $10 for every 24 hours. Another very expensive item was parking where only Valet parking is available and costs $40 per day. There is a cheaper underground car park for $15 per day opposite the hotel in Pershing Square. The swimming pool is very luxurious looking and made a nice start to every day. There is also a choice of both steam room and sauna room and a decent range of gym machines. Jacquzzi needs some of the jets to be fixed, however. Location was excellent if you do not have a car as there is a metro right outside in Pershing square that has a direct train to Hollywood and Universal studios and takes 15 and 20min respectively. There is also a direct bus to Beverely Hills outside the hotel and takes 30min if no traffic. Taxis are expensive in L.A. so having good access to public transport is a plus.

Reviews.Title: “Old world pleasure”
Reviews.Author: printdave
Reviews.Content: Located in Down Town Los Angeles, I found the pricing to be similar to that of much lesser hotels in West Hollywood so value for money was amazing!!! Their standard rooms are massive, clean and quietly elegant! The lobby and all common areas remind one of what you might imagine a Grande Hotel in the old European fashion to be (though really Europe rarely offers such space and elegance at this price!! The staff were friendly and helpful and my overall experience makes me want to return again and again anytime I'm passing through LA! The only draw back is Down Town LA it's self. Outside the hotel most restaurants and activities are non existent after 6pm and Down Town is rather far away from many of the cities tourist venues. Still, the Millenium Biltmore for me was a treat in herself!

Reviews.Title: “NOt what it seems”
Reviews.Author: lovetravel2b
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Millenium Biltmore in Los Angeles for 7 days this past week. I enjoyed my stay in Los Angeles, but the hotel had some problems. First off, when we checked in they lied to us when they told us that they did not have any rooms available because the people don't check out until 2 pm. That was what the front desk girl said. It turns out that they check out at 12pm. She obviously was new, or so I thought. Then when she charged my credit card for the usual incidentals, I asked how much would be held. She stated no more than $300.00, what she failed to mention that in addition there would be an automatic $300.00 tacked on at the end of that same night for a total of $600.00 being held. I asked someone else the next day when I checked my balance and saw that it appeared to be an extra charge, when they told me that it was not extra, that is usual and customary. I felt that it was deceitful. Be up front. Second, the hotel bathroom toilet had problems flushing. The paint was chipping, and the TV was quite small. The area by the pool was so dark and desloate, it was univiting. The exterior of the hotel and the lobby is quite impressive, but it is a rip off. It is convenient to transportation which was our main concern, so that worked out, but food was not cheap in this hotel. It seemed over priced for the ammenities, which were none. I would only stay here if you have to do business in the downtown area.

Reviews.Title: “Hospitality”
Reviews.Author: Awesometeacher78
Reviews.Content: Wow, talk about hospitalityâ€¦ during my husbandâ€™s R&R from Iraq, we decided to take a tour of the California Coast. Upon arriving in Los Angeles, we had no idea of where to go and what to see. We decided to leave our fate in the hands of the concierge, James Russel. Mr. Russel not only gave us great recommendations and exact directions, he also provided us with the best hospitality around. Once Mr. Russel found out that my husband was in the army and was visiting from Iraq, he sent us a card signed by the hotel staff and basket of fruit to our room. I was so impressed with the Biltmore that I would highly recommend it to anyone. Thank you Mr. Russel for caring!

Reviews.Title: “$40 a Night for Parking! Internet Access Fees!”
Reviews.Author: khas107
Reviews.Content: A $40 a night for parking is outragous! They charge for internet access! I was very disappointed not only by these charges, but also for what I consider as being taken advantage of. It is unfair to charge people unreasonable fees when they don't have an other alternative other than never to go back again.

Reviews.Title: “A gem”
Reviews.Author: Roadbum
Reviews.Content: We arrived (by train, so out of our control) at 9 am, in jeans and floppy hats, with hiking poles sticking out of our rucksacks. The front desk people were friendly, courteous, and let us check into our room immediately. The hotel's public areas are, of course, stunning, but I had read some negative comments about the rooms. So we were pleasantly surprised by our spacious, well appointed room. On the third floor, in a standard room, we had a view of Pershing Square. Our total bill for the night including tax and 4 long distance calls was $208. My only complaint was that they charged me $1 each for toll free calls, but I think this is fairly common in some luxury hotels. Anyone who thinks these rooms are small hasn't traveled much outside of the US. I'm looking for an excuse to go back to LA so I can stay there again!

Reviews.Title: “Better than expected!”
Reviews.Author: DRbride2b
Reviews.Content: After booking our incredibly reasonably priced reservation on Expedia, I was a little worried to see so many bad reviews here on TripAdvisor. All I can say is that while some of the comments are valid, the good outweighs the bad at the Biltmore. We were 4 people staying in two rooms for 4 nights. While both rooms were the same price, one of them was really spacious with seating area and a large walk in closet, while the other was more or less a standard sized room. The smaller room also had the inconvenience of sharing an entryway with a locked door with another room, so we couldn't just go knock on our companion's door because they wouldn't hear us. The rooms were clean, though obviously not modern, which two of us found charming and two of us weren't as excited by. The beds were great, the linens were nice and the TV was decent sized. My Mom and I used the pool and the jacuzzi which was really something to see, though not the most functional in that the hot tub couldn't seat more than two people. I would agree with travellers who would say that there is nothing around the hotel and this part of the city is pretty dead in the evenings, but as we had other plans most of the time, this wasn't a problem for us. There are only a few restaurants around, but we found one we really enjoyed and went there twice. There are two big downsides we found. The first was the noise. My home is towndown Montreal and even I found it to be a bit noisy at night and in the early morning. Thicker, more soundproof windows would make a great difference. The second was the price of the valet parking at $40 a day. Yes we could have gone to the parking garage around the corner but we were doing a lot of in and out and it just seemed more convenient. But for that price, we would have expected that when we called ahead to have our car brought round we wouldn't have to wait, which was always the case. A small downside was not having ice on every floor, but that was minor. That said, it really is something to be staying in a hotel with such dramatically beautiful public areas and at least average guest areas. We did get our money's worth.

Reviews.Title: “What's going on with the pool?”
Reviews.Author: rafaelgmartins
Reviews.Content: I've just got back from a trip to Vegas and LA. On July 1st I checked in the Millennium Biltmore Hotel in downtown LA. The hotel is very beautiful. A little too classy for me, but hey, that's not the hotel's fault, probably mine and mostly my travel agent's. The room was great and I really loved the bathroom and the shower. Long baths in the bathtub, great right? So, everything was perfect but then, in the last day before I had to leave I decided to go relax a bit in the pool and in the jacuzzi. What a disappointment! The pool area (wich they call the "health club" because there is also a gym) was awful. Not because is not great itself but it was literally "abandoned" by the hotel staff. Many towels in the floor, liter, and no life guards (but they do have a big sign saying "hey, it's every man (and kid) for himself"). But what was most upsetting was the cold jacuzzi that was not working. "Not working?. Ok, let me get someone from the staff. Ops, where are they? No one is here. Let me try to find a phone. No, no phone either. Ok, finally a phone behind the bar. Can you please send someone here to see why the jacuzzi is not working. 10 minutes later a guy comes, says nothing (like "is everyhing allright?" or even "good evening sir"), turns the machine on and goes away (still not saying a thing). Does the jacuzzi gets any hot? No." Very disappointing. At the same time a weeding reception was happening in the hotel. Maybe they were kind of busy with that, I don't know. I end up forgetting to complain with the hotel, I regret that. Other then that, you should stay there. Not a very expensive hotel and very confortable.

Reviews.Title: “Enjoyed our stay, but probably wouldn't go back”
Reviews.Author: readit
Reviews.Content: We enjoyed our time in Los Angeles at the Biltmore hotel, but if you're going simply for tourism, I would not recommend this hotel. There isn't much going on downtown, aside from business. The rooms were very nice with super comfortable beds, but the washrooms were a bit dated. Overall, nice hotel, but not recommended for tourists.

Reviews.Title: “Nice Hotel”
Reviews.Author: Hyades24
Reviews.Content: The foyer of this hotel looks very flash, and the room we stayed in was pretty nice too. I was a little unimpressed with the quality of the bed-making, as the sheets did not cover the bed. Apart from this, it was a nice place to stay and the concierge was a lovely man. The only other issue was that it's located in Downtown LA, and there's not much there but hotels and office buildings. If you want to be where the action is, I would suggest staying in the Hollywood area.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely hotel”
Reviews.Author: philip861
Reviews.Content: Myself and my girlfreind stayed at the Biltmore for four nights in June 2008, and were quite impressed by the appearance of the hotel and helpfulness of the staff. The location of the Biltmore is excellent, being just across the road from Pershing Square and its metro station. This means that prime tourist sites, such as Hollywood and Universal Studios are only about 20 minutes away. This was important for us because we didn't have a car to travel around. As for the hotel itself, the exterior but particularly the interior of the lobby is impressive. It strikes you as a quality hotel as soon as you walk through the door. The large pictures on the wall are reminiscent of the closing scene in "The Shining"; the corridor leading to the health centre has many photographs of the hotel's history- I thought this was a nice touch. The room we had was a little on the small side, but was otherwise fine. The health centre is an excellent amenity, featuring a swimming pool (which closes at 8 pm, which is a little early I thought), and a fitness centre (which remains open 24 hours). We ordered room service our final night, which was promptly delivered and was delicious. It was probably the best room service I've experienced in fact. The only negative I experienced during my stay was the shower in my room, which ceased to work on our final morning in the hotel, which meant I had to use one in the health centre. All in all, I would recommend this hotel. I got a good deal on hotels.com, and for what I payed my stay was excellent. The staff were courteous throughout and the facilities excellent. If I were to re-visit LA I would consider staying at the Biltmore again.

Reviews.Title: “Run in and take a picture of the lobby and leave!”
Reviews.Author: Ibct
Reviews.Content: Ugh, what a yucko experience. Seriously, the lobby, and most of the main floor is really beautiful, but the rooms, and I ended up staying in two, were NOT WORTH it and actually pretty lousy- needed repairs, not that clean etc. Both rooms were so noisy (in the first room, I could hear people talking and a baby crying, it seemed like they were in MY room; I got to hear the lovely sounds of buses, emergency vehicles and drunk people singing all night in the second room). I ended up moving rooms because when I turned on the shower, some-God- knows-what brown stuff came out of the faucet. When I called down to the Front Desk to let them know what was going on, the answer was "Whaddya want me to do?". I requested another room was able to move, but received no help moving my bags and NO APOLOGY. It almost made me feel like maybe they're used to hearing about brown stuff coming out of their faucets... I received really good service from Housekeeping and from the people who work in the restaurant Smeraldi's, but not from the Front Desk. I would see if you could get a room at the Sheraton if you're going to visit downtown LA, and come and take pictures of the lobby at the Biltmore.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful Stay!”
Reviews.Author: obrn855
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Biltmore during a recent professional nursing convention with some trepidation. I read reviews that described the rooms as shabby & outdated, the staff as unfriendly, and the neighborhood as unsafe. Travelling across the country alone, I was very nervous about what I had gotten myself into. I could not have been happier with my stay & wonder what was going on with those who had a negative experience. To say that the lobby and the common areas of the hotel are stunning is an understatement. Everything speaks to the rich history of this landmark. I especially enjoyed learning about the hotel's role in the glory days of old Hollywood. The staff was friendly and helpful, directing me to the best ways to get around the city and the things to do. Cabs were very easy to come by, thanks to the staff of the hotel, but I chose to walk to and from the Convention Center each day. I did not ever feel unsafe walking alone downtown. I found the facilities to be more than adequate- the fitness center has a lot of equipment (more than I was expecting, based on one review) and was open around the clock. This was great for someone who was out of sorts with the time change and wide awake at 3 a.m. most days, ready to get going. Although I did not eat in the hotel much, I had a wonderful, if pricey, breakfast at Smeraldi's. For more value, there's a great little coffee shop around the corner on 6th, called the Yorkshire Grill, where I got a delicious breakfast for less than $10, including tip. My room was charming & comfortable. The mattresses have, indeed, been upgraded and the linens were crisp, clean, and of high quality. Yes, the TV was a little small, but who needs to spend much time watching TV when you're in LA? If I wanted to nitpick, I'd say that the bathtub could have been re-glazed. Other than that, my room was perfect. I met several other people staying at other local hotels for the convention who stated they would have rather been at the Biltmore.

Reviews.Title: “Deceptive booking - do not trust”
Reviews.Author: parkedr
Reviews.Content: I just checked in with a friend to stay one night in downtown LA to see a concert. I specifically booked the hotel because they told me that I could have a room with two double beds. First of all, the line to check in took 20 minutes. When I finally arrived in my room, it was a single king bed. Of course, the clerk that checked me in made no mention of this. I didn't have my reservation in hand when I called to front desk to complain and the clerk actually lied to me and told me that I had booked a room for a single adult. As soon as I logged into my computer, I found that my reservation was, as I had thought, for two adults and two twin beds. Needless to say, I am angry. I could have easily booked a room that I wanted at another hotel if this one wasn't deceptive. Basically, don't believe a word these people say. There are better hotels for the money in downtown LA.

Reviews.Title: “Don't miss afternoon tea at the Biltmore!”
Reviews.Author: oyster13
Reviews.Content: If you find yourself having to stay in downtown LA, do it in style at the Millennium Biltmore. Sure, the rooms may not be as modern as in other nearby big hotels, but this hotel has real character and an impressive history. The grand lobby is stunning, as is the ballroom that hosted some early Academy Award ceremonies. Afternoon tea in the Rendezvous Court was a great experience and not too be missed -- the service, food and setting were excellent. The room showed its age somewhat, but was clean, spacious and had a lovely ensuite bathroom. However, despite being located on a high floor, the room could be noisy at times from street noise. Still, as a business traveller, it was nice to stay at a large hotel that had a distinctive feel.

Reviews.Title: “Elegant European Masterpiece - stop your moaning!!!!”
Reviews.Author: zoids
Reviews.Content: I feel obliged to write this given the complaints I read from other reviewers. What a bunch of perfectionists. This hotel was great from check-in to check-out. The staff were without exception attentive, helpful & polite. The public spaces sparkled. Loved the Pool and the Bar. The Ballrooms were amazing. Our room was spacious with a view of the park & the outdoor ice-rink. It felt individual (not like a chain hotel) & was spotlessly clean. I cannot understand complaints from other reviewers about the fascilities. If you want to stay at a Hilton/Ramada etc etc then please feel free. Leave the Biltmore to those travellers who appreciate old world charm with great service. I would choose to ban the business travellers as they just spoil the ambience of places like this. I would stay in this hotel above pretty much any other I have visited in the States and I have stayed in many of the very best. Thank you to all who made this stay so memorable.

Reviews.Title: “Grand old hotel, and it shows in spots”
Reviews.Author: CapTraveler4
Reviews.Content: We ended up at the Biltmore downtown as part of a group attending a convention nearby. This was my first trip to Los Angeles, and I was a little surprised to discover how little is actually going on downtown, especially after 5pm, when it turns into a bit of a ghost town. There is a Metro stop a couple blocks away, but the public transit system in LA leaves a lot to be desired. As for the hotel itself, most of the reviews that I've read on here are fairly accurate. The hotel is ancient by LA standards, and it shows in the rooms. The lobby and bar areas are very elegant and grand, and they set up your expectations of the rooms perhaps a little too high. When we got to the room we were quite underwhelmed. It was clean enough, but it's just very old. The door to the bathroom was heavy and creaked, the TV was laughable (I think it was 19", and it was very old), and the bed itself was just OK. The mattress was clearly past its prime, although we did see a bunch of new mattresses being loaded into the hotel one day. Apparently they are going to replace all the mattresses this summer. I did enjoy the pool, which is a great old Roman tile type pool, although it would be better if it was open later (closes at 8). The workout room was small but will suffice if you're just looking to jump on the treadmill for 30 mins. The worst part of our stay was getting stuck in an elevator. We were going from the 5th floor down to the lobby when the elevator just stopped. We got management on the phone and they were very concerned and responsive, but there's not much you can do to console people when they're stuck in an elevator. We were in there for about 5 minutes (felt like an hour) when the elevator suddenly sprang back into action, went down to the lobby and the doors opened. Management met us there and seemed very concerned for our well being, although they had no explanation for why the elevator malfunctioned. They offered us passes to the buffet breakfast, which was a nice token gesture but at that point we just wanted to get out of there and go for a walk. The Biltmore clearly is an LA landmark that has seen better days. Without major hotel-wide renovations I don't think we'd stay here again. Certainly don't stay here expecting modern amenities.

Reviews.Title: “Millenium Biltmore - grand ole hotel fraying at the edges”
Reviews.Author: jma236
Reviews.Content: My DH and I stayed at the Millenium Biltmore as a part of a business trip for 2 nights in mid May. We chose it mostly because the price was right and the location was reasonable - good access to highways, and close by to some friends. The hotel is a historic property and there is ample evidence of old grandeur in the lobby, bar, and restaurants, which are really quite lovely. It certainly evokes a different era when you step through the doors into the hotel. Our room was suprisingly large with a view of downtown LA. We also had a very large walk in closet - the size of some kitchens in NYC. The bathroom was good sized and had a seperate tub and shower. The shower did not have any place to put anything other than a bar of soap which was a negative. The room has a box TV, desk, and chair. The biggest problem with the room is when you walk in, the first thing you see are very dated linens on the beds. The comforter is literally fraying at the edges and losing its color. The linens were of poor quality and need to be replaced. The carpet in the room was also coming up at the edges of the room and also was not high quality. Those are not things you would expect to encounter at a 4 star hotel. We also could have done without the prom on the Saturday evening of our stay. The lobby turned into an impromptu photo studio and those attending the prom spent a good deal of their time shuttling b/t the dance floor and various hotel rooms in a loud manner. Valet parking is $40 per day, and our car was always ready when we requested it. The hotel charges a fee for internet usage per day. Check in and check out were quick and painless. We did not eat at the restaurants or go to the bar in the hotel. Ultimately this hotel is a high end 3 star hotel, but the above mentioned problems keep it from attaining the 4 star status. Although we would stay at this hotel again if the price was right, we would not seek it out as a place to stay.

Reviews.Title: “Not the best choice in downtown L.A.”
Reviews.Author: sakio
Reviews.Content: I really wanted to like this hotel, but can't say I could recommend it to anyone. First of all, I want to say the people that worked there were great. The front desk person checked me in really early and was about as nice as a person could get. The cleaning crew was always smiling and saying "hi" so I can't say anything but good things about them. The problems with this hotel are three things: 1. The hotel building is old. Sure, it's beautiful at the lobby level (actually stunning), but that age also makes the rooms small. I'm sure it may have been sufficient in the 1930's, but it's not even remotely up to par for the 21st Century. The bathroom fixtures are old and they make a lot of noise. 2. The room decoration was really cheap. The desk looked like something out of the Sears outdoor furniture collection and the TV.....a 13 incher. C'mon, I can accept the limitations of an old hotel, but a 13 inch TV obviously built in the late 70's or early 80"s. I just couldn't believe my eyes. Motel 6's have better TV's than that. 3. The street noise, just awful. I've read the management notes on other reviews regarding this and I understand their point, but half of the rooms face the outside streets. You could do better on the lower floors with better insulated windows. I've stayed at older hotels all over the country on business. I've seen how it could be done well. The Roosevelt in Hollywood, The Adolphus in Dallas, the Michelangelo in NYC and the Palace in San Francisco do it right. The Millenium needs to upgrade to be up to the standards of other classic hotels.

Reviews.Title: “Really expected a lot more”
Reviews.Author: hola_y_saludos
Reviews.Content: I was recently at the Biltmore for a business meeting. When I came to check in, despite the fact that we had made reservations weeks ahead, I was told there were no rooms left. A professional acquaintance of mine happened to arrive a little after I did and after we greeted each other, I was asked by the front desk if we would mind sharing a room!!! Despite not being happy about it, we acquiesced, given that there were "no rooms left." Ultimately, after about 45 minutes, we were given a suite that had separate bedrooms, which was fine, but I had not intended to share a hotel room with someone I barely knew... The room was clean, but I must say I expected a little more in quality-the pillows (dense foam) were extremely uncomfortable and the polyester blankets were too hot. I also have to comment that I am extremely disappointed with the service. I had had a package shipped to the hotel in anticipation of a morning meeting the next day. By the time I got up to my hotel room after the check-in fiasco, it was already after 10:00 pm. I'd been told by the front desk that the package would be sent up to my room. At 10:45 pm it still was not there, so I called down to the front desk and informed them I was going to sleep and to please bring it in the morning before my 8:30 meeting. When it had not come in the morning before I had to go to the meeting, I went to the front desk, who sent me to the bell desk, who then called down to the shipping room to locate the package. They asked me to wait while they went downstairs to retrieve it rather than just bringing it to the meeting room. While the building is quite regal and ornate, the service leaves a lot to be desired.

Reviews.Title: “Management Is Horrible”
Reviews.Author: empresz
Reviews.Content: The room itself was nothing to write home about. But just remember that this IS a historic property. So for that experience alone, I do recommend the Biltmore. The upside to staying here is the great location as well as lobby area. It is absolutely beautiful. But my compliments end there. I had a very bad experience during my stay which happened to be my wedding weekend. My sister called the Biltmore a few days later to complain and was treated so horribly by MANAGEMENT that I still can't get over it -- and it has been over six months! The childishness of the management does not end there, but no need to get into the gory details. Anyways, I wouldn't stay at the Biltmore again if my life depended on it.

Reviews.Title: “Landed on our feet”
Reviews.Author: betty_travelsUK
Reviews.Content: We ended up here while backpacking round California, we booked it last minute as we couldnt seem to find a hostel which had a good safe location. We managed to get it for a very reasonable rate and found it excellent. Didnt agree with the negative reviews had read on here but thought we may have been seeing it from a different perspective. We were aiming for a dorm in a hostel and upgraded rather a lot to this. Excellent services, lovely rooms clean, spacious if not a little out of date in their decoration. The cocktail bar and sports bar were great catering for both ends of the market in terms of price. Location wasn't amazing, was ok in the day as there were shops, cafes etc around as well as a few attractions but at night there wasn't that much to do. However there is a metro station just opposite the hotel which meant it was easy to access other areas of the city. Also close to a bus stop for the Big Blue Bus which runs to Santa Monica for a very reasonable price. In terms of price and value for money we were very pleased and would stay there again without a doubt.

Reviews.Title: “The loudest hotel EVER”
Reviews.Author: Will_this_name_take
Reviews.Content: Stayed here last night and will be staying for the next 2 because everything in LA is sold out due to conferences and NBA Playoffs. To start the lobby is stunning, desk service is great, and the bar is breath taking. I stay at hotels every week for work of varying quality so Iâ€™m not a typical civilian when it comes to hotels. With this in mind I have to say this way the LOUDEST hotel I have ever stayed. Between the street traffic and the room doors slamming at all hours I got little to no sleep. Most hotels have loud AC systems that you can kick up to create a white noise buffer to mask the surrounding noise but this place has the quietest AC systems I have encountered. The windows are single pane which does nothing to keep the constant street noise out. My coworker slept with ear plugs and said that they made little difference. The rooms are pretty stark as well; no art work or head boards in the room I was given. I will not stay here again if I can help it.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful hotel”
Reviews.Author: Jack1970
Reviews.Content: We arrived as walk-in guests, which means without reservation. Check-in went smootly, (bath)room was spacious and very luxurious, room-service was excellent and the bartender made the best margarita I ever had. This hotel is great for your business trip! During our stay there was a wedding party going on and we took a peek into the ballroom; What a luxury! The dining tables, the decorations, the flowers...everything was just perfect!

Reviews.Title: “I'd stay again”
Reviews.Author: NorCalHereAndThere
Reviews.Content: Yes, it is an old hotel complete with grand lobby. The guest rooms definitely show their age and the bathroom was small. But I am glad they have not applied liberal amounts of botox (unlike the rest of LA) . The age is part of the charm. The biggest problem is that my third floor room was too close to the smoking floor and the smoke filled the elevator area on the non-smoking level. Bad, very bad. Who still allows smoking anyway? If you hate smoke, you should ask how close you are to the smoking floor before accepting the room. The bar was nice. Greg, the bartender, has a fabulous drink called a "French Kiss." If you like the girly, sweet martini, this is a must. The staff was pleasant and accomodating, the rates are reasonable. I'm not a big fan of LA in general, but if business calls me back again, I hope I can stay at the Biltmore.

Reviews.Title: “Good value for price”
Reviews.Author: mailer1
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the Biltmore for one night. For the price we paid, the rooms were fine - bathroom a little dated, but clean and plenty of towels. Bed was comfortable and the sheets were definitely clean and crisp. Having read some of the reviews, I checked! Also, didn't experience the issues with thin walls mentioned in other reviews. Overall, no complaints. The concierge was helpful and recommended a great little steakhouse. For the time I was in LA, this was a good choice. It isn't a modern, chic boutique, but it does have masses of character if that is what you like. A grand old lady.

Reviews.Title: “Loved the Millenium Biltmore”
Reviews.Author: trioogy
Reviews.Content: This hotel was great! My husband and I booked here, after realizing the cost was so great for what you get. There is so much nostalgia and ambiance here. They have a quaint little jazz bar with great service, and the only true dissappointment was the parking fee, but it is downtown LA.

Reviews.Title: “The Biltmore is HORRENDOUS”
Reviews.Author: Adamgana
Reviews.Content: I am just finishing up a two-week stay at the Millenium Biltmore. I had to travel to L.A. for business and needed a hotel downtown. I was told that the Biltmore was a nice place with good services. Unfortunately, that could not be farther from the truth. Although the common areas of the hotel are beautiful, the roooms are badly outdated. The bed is extremely uncomfortable and the bathroom is tiny and grimy. The hotel "gym" is nothing more than a hallway with some old free weights and equally old cardio machines. The most disturbing thing about the hotel, however, is the utter lack of professionalism of its staff. Other than the concierge, the staff is unfriendly, not knowledgeable and generally unhelpful. The laundry service is ridiculously expensive which is not unusual, but it is untimely, often taking a day longer than promised, which is totally unacceptable when you are trying to do business. I recommend that anyone considering this hotel reconsider immediately. You will absolutely be disappointed in your choice. The Hilton Checkers is across the street and is a much nicer and professional establishment. I will never stay at the Millenium again.

Reviews.Title: “amazing interior”
Reviews.Author: MissNippy
Reviews.Content: The lobby of this hotel is stunning. Check-in was quick and efficient. The rooms were a little disappointing - the beds were very comfortable, but the bathroom was really small. Whilst the staff in the restuarant weren't rude, they were very abrupt and could be more cheerful. The concierge was very helpful with providing advice and helping to book airport transfers.

Reviews.Title: “Not what I reserved!”
Reviews.Author: mcstrangelove
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed at the Millennium Biltmore for the 2008 LA Marathon. I made the reservation in December 2007 and was told by the hotel's customer service that we would be guaranteed a room with a single king bed. Simple enough. The day we checked in, our room had 2 full beds. At the rate we were paying, we could've at least gotten the room we requested. We contacted the front desk and were told: There's nothing we can do, we're sold out. I asked to speak to a manager and was told the manager was unavailable for the night! Sure, the place has a cool lobby and the staff is friendly for the most part, but what does it matter if you don't get what you reserved?

Reviews.Title: “Classy hotel for quiet, adult, relaxation”
Reviews.Author: T_and_TShantyBay
Reviews.Content: We decided to stay here as a relaxing end to a cruise we were on out of Long Beach, and we are glad we chose this hotel. We arrived much earlier than check-in time , but were given our rooms early without any hassle. We were looking for an older-style hotel and this was it - in a good way. Beautiful architecture, upgraded interior without overdoing it. I see complaints that it looks "tired" - that's great. We loved looking at the history, we liked that certain things had been upgraded to modern facilities but not overdone. We really enjoyed the fact that this is not your typical holiday Inn, it has class and therefore we weren't disturbed by lot's of children running around. The meals in the Smeraldi restaurant were excellent, we were spoiled ! The only complaint would be more selections on the menu to choose from. Afternoon tea in the original lobby was a delightful experience. Every member of the staff greeted us with a smile and a hello, except the person at the front desk, who was polite, helpful and efficient, but seemed tired. The bar staff was also top notch. Another reviewer complained about traffic noise - you're downtown, it's a classic (older) building - what do you expect ? I'm sure all you had to is request another room. It did not bother us, and we live out in the country where there is no noise, so we are used to quiet. Minor complaints - empty tissue box in the room, cheap tv (although we weren't there to watch tv), the bed had a slight dip in the middle. Expensive cab ride to anywhere (not the hotels fault) We loved this hotel and would definitely stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful lobby/so/so rooms”
Reviews.Author: HappyNCTraveler
Reviews.Content: I agree with most of the other reviews. The lobby areas are absolutely beautiful--felt like I was in a fine art museum. Even the ceilings are magnificent. I also liked the historical nature of the hotel--with pictures of the original Academy Awards banquets held here. The back lobby near the restaurants is a quiet and elegant place to have coffee or a light breakfast from the coffee bar located there. We were there on the weekend and found the area to be quiet, safe and clean. We walked to the MOMA and Disney Concert Hall easily and quickly. Now, the rooms are as described, although ours may have been better than some. It was very large and clean, but there was a large empty area near the doorway which could have benefited from a sofa or easy chairs. It was simply empty. Also, the towels in the bathroom were thin and hard--that would be easy enough to fix despite the "historic nature" of the hotel. There was a large stain on one bedspread and the desk was badly peeling paint with a piece of glass over it. A simple paint job would take care of that. I probably would stay there again due to location and beauty of the public areas, but would ask if there are any recently renovated rooms.

Reviews.Title: “Very disappointed !”
Reviews.Author: hemdale
Reviews.Content: I went to this hotel for professional reasons and I stayed there for 1 week. The staff was not really helpful. My room was disgusting. Used tissues on the floor on my arrival, dusty furniture and curtains, dirty windows ! What a shame for a "I don't think so" 4 **** hotel ! Restaurants in the hotel are overpriced. Don't ever, never go to this hotel ! It's a shame to see this in 2007/08 ! If I knew, I would have gone to the Standard Hotel (by far a MUCH better choice for the SAME price !)

Reviews.Title: “Snobby, not worth the price TIRED and VERY OLD OLD OLD fashioned”
Reviews.Author: abrandbutler
Reviews.Content: Very disappointed! We have stayed in this hotels numerous times and it only gets worse and worse. We will not return. Children are not allowed in the Club room. we were told "they are a liability." This, I guess is a newer policy and exceptionally prejudicial. Run away, do NOT STAY AT THIS HOTEL!

Reviews.Title: “Never Again!”
Reviews.Author: jendavedj
Reviews.Content: We booked this part of our trip on Priceline ($90/nt) after a stay @ Disneyland. We were excited about staying at a 4 star property right in Downtown LA. I had HOPED for the Omni, but got the Biltmore, but was willing to give it a shot. I should of known from the get-go of $40/nt to park, that I was in for the unexpected! PS- park in Pershing Square for $14/nt(which is RIGHT across the street) The lobby was beautiful but the ladies at the check-in counter were not what I'd expect at a 4 star property--lazy looking and not friendly, very unprofessional and probably not that fluent in English. The hotel is old and I took that into consideration. Our room was on the 8th floor and we found it to be comparable to a 2 star hotel back home in CO. It had basic ammenities (ie. bath, beds, desk, tv). I've stayed at several hotels and this has to rate as one of the worst in this category--it's a Super 8 quality. I expected MUCH more! You had to pay to use the phone (even local calls), the internet, etc. The restaurants are overpriced. Watch out for the "bar" window in the tea area-- 2 whiskey and cokes = $30. The pool area needs updating. The ambience and the look of the tiles, made it feel run down and dirty--time to brighten up your basement "oasis"!! Unlike other reviewers, we didn't find noise to be a problem. Few tips for future guests: 1) use your cell phones and go to the public library a block away for internet 2) downtown LA closes on the weekends in PM including restaurants and Starbucks--I kid you NOT! Strangest phenomona I saw my whole trip! 3)there's a Domino's pizza on the same block which we utitlized 2 times b/c there were no other choices on a Sunday night 4)don't ask the staff to aid you in finding anything outside of the hotel. we asked where the closest food or McDs was and they sent us to "Little Mexico" --SCARY! 5) don't expect the gentlemen in the suits by the entrance doors to open them for you--not sure what their "job" is but obviously not to interact w/ guests. After a 3 day stay--never again will I venture to the Biltmore, nor to downtown LA--it was a HUGE disappointment for a first time Cali trip!

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful place, can't say enough!”
Reviews.Author: jsimp
Reviews.Content: My daughter (17) and and I spent a weekend in LA to see the sights. We got a great rate from Hotels.com and the stay exceeded both our expectations. The staff was outstanding from front desk to floor maids. The decor is just breathtaking! The pool area was a throwback to the art deco era. The rooms are tastefully decorated and comfortable. The lobby is a real stunner! Much has been written about the parking fees. The valet parking was a lifesaver after a long day of siteseeing, and also great to have the car brought out first thing as we started our day. Parking valets were AWESOME! They were courteous and friendly. I never felt like tipping was required, they were very personable and efficient. I was more than satisfied with the service. I would not hesitate to stay there again. Perfect for a girls weekend! Everyone from valet attendants to concierge were cheerful and helpful. HINT: if renting a car, bring or rent a GPS system. That saved our nerves and made the weekend stress-free as we traveled from LA, to Hollywood, to Venice, to Anaheim, to Beverly HIlls. No small feat for two Midwesterers!

Reviews.Title: “Old world grandeur”
Reviews.Author: Papaleadfoot
Reviews.Content: Old world grandeur at this downtown hotel. Rooms are varied in size. Our "smoking" club floor room was very large; immaculate with a European decor flavor. The downside was the "one person only" bathroom with its ancient fixtures in really urgent need of upgrade. That is just a "heads-up", not enough of a problem to keep you away. Staff was nice, courteous...almost. Their Sports Bar was very busy; the staff was unable to cope with the situation exemplified by the person answering the phone stating they were too busy to answer how long a wait there was for a table there. Fortunately, there are other choices in the hotel as well as nearby. If you are looking for a downtown hotel, the property is a good option. (Especially if you are into buying wholesale jewelry since the jewelry marts are close by.)

Reviews.Title: “Gentleman Club feeling”
Reviews.Author: simonkklee
Reviews.Content: Bang in the middle of downtown LA where there really is nothing to do. Around the corner was a Starbucks and few other small sandwich shops but nothing spectacular or interesting. It's close enough to all the freeways if you need to drive and in that sense it's very convenient. We hired a car and it took us maybe 30 mins to drive from the airport. They were charging US$40 a night for parking which you can take the car in and out as you please - usual tips to the drivers. There is parking a plenty around the hotel and prices were about US$20 but I never could be bothered to park and walk to the hotel. I think GRAND is the word you can use to describe the hotel. It's got a nice entrance, lobby, bar and restaurant. Very acceptable. The gym is quite old as is the equipment - feels like you're working out in an old turkish bath area. Rooms are OK... big and spacious but the beds are way too soft. It can get quite noisy being downtown (the occasional fire engine or police car screaming past). There's no kettle in the room so you have to use the coffee machine to boil your water. I paid about US$190 per night, staying for 2 nights. Not bad overall... but I'd prob want to try another hotel next time I'm in LA. Didn't do enough to convince me to stay again.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Common Spaces, Rooms are Tired”
Reviews.Author: DCArea-Susan
Reviews.Content: I stayed here for 5 nights in conjunction with a business-related symposium at the convention center. Common spaces are beautiful - very grand, elegant, and ornate. I would describe my room as "tired" and in need of some refurbishment and a good cleaning. There were no wash cloths the first night, an ice bucket liner was not provided, (and the self that holds the ice bucket in the ice machine was missing), my night stand was dirty, there was a black hair in one of the bathroom glasses, grout and spackle had not been cleaned off the tub enclosure and tiles, I found a black bobby pin on the floor, one of two safes in my room had been left locked (the bigger, more easily accessible one which could hold a lap top) and the handicap grab bar in my bathtub was broken. The repair man came to fix the grab bar while I was unpacking and I shooed him away until the next day. It was not fixed the next evening when I returned to my room. I did complain to the front desk about the grab bar and the safe. The grab bar was fixed. There are very limited dining options on Sunday evenings - both Sai Sai and the sports bar were closed (and there were two play-off games that evening!). An imported beer at the bar cost me $6.50 but you are given a bowl of mixed nuts (no peanuts) that is refilled. I thought the food at Esmereldi's was very good, but pricy ($12 for my glass of wine), however, subsequent dining in the downtown area at other restaurants revealed this to be in line with other nice dining options. The food at Sai Sai was also very good, but pricy.

Reviews.Title: “Dissapointed”
Reviews.Author: Gabe712
Reviews.Content: My problems with the room are; the bed, Room 659 (or 569.. i forget) DID NOT have a king size bed like i requested. It looked more like a full. I asked for a smoking room and could NOT find an ashtray. Besides the shower handles that felt like they were going to come through the wall.. water pressure was miserable! And the toilet.. looked like something you see in jail movies.. didn't even have a cover. I realize the Biltmore is an older "classic" hotel, but i've seen nicer rooms at budget motels. Anyhow, I don't feel like i got what i paid for. In the hotels defense.. I was in a hurry and did not have time to allow them to address my concerns.

Reviews.Title: “RUN!!!! Star Wars Bar...No, I mean Hotel”
Reviews.Author: mbagf7
Reviews.Content: Do not stay! Don't pay attention to the photos or anything you read that makes you think it is worth the price. Before I arrived I call the night Supervisor to confirm my reservation. "I will tell you what you what the room will be..just listen" as she barked the difference between adjoining and two rooms next to each other. Very rude. The other comment I got when I called and said that the hotel had mixed reviews online was..."those people should not complain, it is not like they are going to live here." Management needs to read the comments and respond..or just change the management. The stay just confirmed it all..run the other way!!!!

Reviews.Title: “Worst experience ever!”
Reviews.Author: JuhnsTraveler
Reviews.Content: Please do not stay at this hotel. I cannot believe they are still in business. I checked in on Sunday night on thanksgiving week. 15 min later I wanted my car so that I can park outside of the hotel since their parking fee is $35 a night. When I got my car back, my car was damaged. They told me to fill out their accident report and told me someone will call me back. Next day no one called me so I complaint at front desk. They told me that is none of their business, as parking is outsourced to different company. Until today 2 weeks after thanksgiving, I still not have received any call from them. I might have to fix the car myself out of my insurance. Very unprofessional and they do not care about customers at all.

Reviews.Title: “Biltmore Millenium Beautiful Foyer, good restaurants, terrible rooms”
Reviews.Author: Hurricanejazz
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the Millenium in October for Work for 5 nights, in downtown LA. Not a lot going on in Downtown LA after 5PM. We were working a convention at the Convention center. Hotel: Anyways walking into the hotel - it is impressive. Beautiful foyer, chandeliers, high end restaurants, etc.. Hustling and Bustling. Great to go here for dinner but not to stay the night. The fitness center and pool are great also. Restaurants: Esmereldi's good food and good breakfast but pricey. Sai Sai - Expensive Sushi, but really good food and atmosphere. Sports Bar: A little dirty but the good pub fare. Rooms: This is where the Millenium lacks. Old carpets, small rooms, old beds, really old TV's and they were small. Getting the internet was a pain. Long hallways to walk down. Bathrooms had poor water pressure. Overall: The Millenium is historic, but it peaked in the 1940's when Dean Martin and company used to ang out there - as is seen in pictures all over the property. Not a great place for Business Travellers.

Reviews.Title: “Old World Charm”
Reviews.Author: mas709
Reviews.Content: I was in LA for business and spent 2 nights at the Biltmore in downtown LA. It is a grand old hotel, which has both pros and cons. The pros include a room with high ceilings and wide entryways, which give one the feeling of space. The furnishings are tasteful, if a bit dated. Closet / dresser space is limited, though. The main drawback for me was the lack of electrical outlets and the outdated (at least in appearance) nature of the existing ones. The rest of the hotel itself offers fantastic photo ops, from the ornate lobby and grand hall to the dining room frescoes and chandeliers...even the pool / fitness center! I would recommend this hotel if you are staying in the downtown area, although there is not a great deal to do in the evenings.

Reviews.Title: “One would expect much more!”
Reviews.Author: londontravellista
Reviews.Content: I have booked this hotel via British Airways and BA e-mailed them, I e-mailed them several times with my simple requests regarding a quiet room with good views. Miranda in Reservations said no problems but what I have experienced was completely different. The hotel's common areas on the ground floor are simly majestic (a mixture between Alphonso XIII in Seville and Nacional de Cuba in Havana). However this is where the beauty stops, as my room had no views (imagine a U shaped wall and my window at the base at the U - limited views). The most upsetting though after spending all this time on e-mails was the room location on a busy hallway.
