It was very difficult to sleep (after a 11h flight and 8h difference with London) with all the disconsiderate young girls shouting on the hallway up to 3am LA time (the doors were so thin), nevermind the engine like permanent noise that came from somewhere outside (probably underground) that made even things in the bathroom vibrate). The room did not have double glazing was very basic and looks like a 2 or 3 star hotel. I was offered a room on the next floor but just above, so probably the same problems. At 4am I went to the Business Room to print 2 pages that cost me together with 6min spent online the amount of almost 7 dollars (could be pricey for the Americans). It seems to me the hotel would more suit a big noisy group and not quiet tired people. The receptionist said the hotel does not have plans for a future renovation (the bathroom would definitely benefit). At 7am I checked out and just after 8am I was comfortably checked in Beverly Hilton (that's what I call outstanding service). Based on the lack of sleep and presentation I would rate my experience as terrible and the hotel as a 3 star only.

Reviews.Title: “Very tired room”
Reviews.Author: isolde
Reviews.Content: Got the room for $100 on Priceline, which is a fair price for downtown LA. Needed a hotel near the Disney concert hall, but would never stay here again. It's a huge place, the public areas are quite beautiful, but the room was very, very tired. Mostly based on the fact that the bathroom hadn't been renovated in 35 years or more, mismatched tiles, etc. The housekeeping standard is terrible--thick layer of dust on the bathroom lights and the ventilation grills. I also expect much higher quality beds if you're going to claim this is a 4 star hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Loved it!”
Reviews.Author: WorldTraveller777
Reviews.Content: I stayed in this hotel in September 2007. Before making a reservation I read all reviews of which many were very contradictory and that made me a little worried. Some people rated the hotel as 'terrible' while the others 'excellent': What's 'dump' for one is a 'lovely place' for another. You can not expect the hotel to be brand new if people have stayed there before you and certainly will after you. Nobody is going to paint the walls after each guest leaves!!! What I'm trying to say is that the reviews are very helpful but at the same time you should not take it as 100% truth. When I checked in with a party of 10 people, the staff was very helpful and we were checked in prompthly. The rooms were big, nicely decorated and very clean. I loved the hotel and would stay here again in a hearbeat!

Reviews.Title: “Very disappointing”
Reviews.Author: JillyCLondon
Reviews.Content: We stayed at this hotel as part of a road trip; it was the most expensive hotel of the stay and the most disappointing at the same time. Very snooty reception desk, surprising as most of the clientele were dressed casually. We were given one of the worst rooms in the place, dank, dark and dusty. We complained immediately and someone on the front desk said they would allocate another room but this didn't materialise until I had phoned the front desk a further FOUR times, not what one needs after a long journey when all you want to do is unpack and take a shower. The room we were given was slightly better but still disappointing. On the plus side we met a couple of very nice staff members, the concierges could not have been more helpful and the lady who served in the bar was lovely. Do think carefully before booking this, I wish we had gone for something like the Chateau Marmont or similar now.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel, lots of history”
Reviews.Author: ray-josh
Reviews.Content: Definately a great place to stay in the heart of historic downtown LA. I booked it thru priceline, I bid 90 dollars for a 4 star in Downtown and came out with this one. Be sure to try to find parking in one of the public lots or street parking though, once you pull in the hotel lot, you are virtually blocked in and have to pay 32 bucks for valet. Not worth it when you can park outside for like 10 bucks or even less. Also, 30 bucks for a sandwich and water is a bit pricey for my style so you may wanna steer clear of room service. If you dont use priceline you will end up paying $150+. Bathroom door wouldnt lock closed and the bathroom was pretty small but the room was huge and had lots of class. I would stay there again for sure, if thats where Priceline sends me.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely all round hotel”
Reviews.Author: Edge18
Reviews.Content: Well all I can say is perfect. We were a bit apprehensive as it was our first time in LA and we had read some mixed reviews. All I can say it we found every aspect of the hotel to be fine. All the staff, receptionist, bellboy, valet etc were all very helfpful and friendly. We had a standard room and it was adequate, with a coffee maker and a power shower!!!!!! The location is ideal to get out and about ,and there are shops, bars and restaurants all close by. We went out both during the day and night and felt quite safe.The hotel arranged a tour of la and hollywood for us and this was again very informative and valu for money. We were collected and taken to meet the tour bus and returned to the hotel afterwards. I know that others have complained about the valet costs which do seem high 39 dollars, but when you look around this an average for all the hotels in the LA area. Mrs Edge, liverpool, uk

Reviews.Title: “Just OK”
Reviews.Author: cobaltblue
Reviews.Content: The hotel reception looks very nice and it seems as if all the guests at the time were business travelers. The hotel staff is rude. The room was very noisy and could not open the windows because of the noise and because other rooms would have looked right in. I also could not figure out how to work the heater so we were cold. The room had a big tv, a radio alarm clock, the bed was nice and there were several lamps that you had to light while walking all the way from the front door to the window in the dark. The bathroom was very small but it had the necessary amenities. All in all it was OK. The area is great during business hours but otherwise it is not good.

Reviews.Title: “History Comes Alive Here!”
Reviews.Author: NancyClaire
Reviews.Content: This is an amazing hotel for those who appreciate the beauty of early 20th century architecture. The hotel opened in 1923 and still retains most of that early grandeur. The hotel is clean, large, and stylish. My room had two double beds and was an average size. It was more than fine. Restaurants are on the expensive side, but it is Los Angeles. The neighborhood is in the heart of downtown. As a female alone, I did not feel nervous or uncomfortable about the area at all. People who complain about the area must be making their first trip of a lifetime to the big city! Have they never seen a homeless person? I loved the Biltmore and can't wait to go back!!

Reviews.Title: “Simply beautiful!”
Reviews.Author: TravelAdvice101
Reviews.Content: What a beautiful hotel! Everything from the lobby area to the hallways and the architecture was beautiful! I stayed in one of the Club Rooms (business travelers) on the 10th / 11th floor. One of the perks of these rooms is that you have access to the business lounge on the 10th floor which offers continental breakfast in the morning and refreshments in the evening (all inclusive of your room rate). Keep in mind, you are paying a higher room rate, so not sure if it's necessarily worth it for leisure travelers. The breakfast was average (coffee, juices, cereal, fruit & yogurt, and some pastries) and the evening refreshments consisted of sodas, crackers & cheese & meat, fruits, and cookies. It was a nice set-up in a lounge area with tables and couches and flat screen tv's. Internet access is also free should you have access to the lounge. Speaking of Internet access, it costs $9.95 for a 24 hr period from your room. Also, because the building is older, wireless reception is not that great and the signal quite weak. Make sure to bring an ethernet cable along to plug into. Cell phone reception is also quite weak -- mine kept fading in and out depending on where I was in the hotel/room, so beware of that. The room size was awesome. So much floor space and a sitting area with couch and table also. Not sure if this was just available for Club Rooms, or it's a standard feature. The only disappointment was the bathroom size. On one hand you have a HUGE room with TONS of floor space and even a walk-in closet, yet the bathroom was TINY with not much room to move in at all. Also, the tub was in bad shape -- cracks in the drainage area. I think the bathroom needed a renovation. All in all, great place to stay. Excellent location, if you want to be in downtown. Seems like there were quite a few restaurants in the area. I didn't have much time to get out, so I grabbed a bite at Smeraldi's one night and Sai Sai the next night. Both restaurants are within the hotel. Smeraldi's is Italian with a Meditteranean touch. Really great food and excellent creme brulee! Best I've had in LA so far! Sai Sai is a Japanese place. Beautiful setting and excellent service.

Reviews.Title: “Great Stay For Mom and 16 Year Old Daughter”
Reviews.Author: Traveler16Chicago
Reviews.Content: My 16 year old daughter and I spent 7 nights in early August. This was a "her choice" vacation. We found the Biltmore to be a perfect central location to all the "touristy" things she wanted to do -- 2 days at Venice Beach/Santa Monica Pier (rent the chopper bikes for 2 hours...sooo fun), a day at the San Diego Wild Animal Park, 2 days shopping on Melrose/Robertson (of course), 1 day on Catalina Island, 1 day at Disneyland. The hotel was perfect for us -- an easy drive to everything, large very, very nice room and bathroom. We looked at the fitness center, which would have been fine, but we were too busy to use it. A solid 3 star hotel. Staff was fine for the little time we spent there. Parking in the underground across the street for $14 instead of valet at the hotel was perfect for us --- we felt completely safe even returning to the hotel as late as midnight. We had a few dinners at the fast food places within walking distance of the hotel (we weren't in LA to eat) and several lovely late desserts at the "fancy" hotel restaurants. The Biltmore was a pleasant surprise and we would definitely go back. We both highly recommend it.

Reviews.Title: “Charm & Location Commingle at the Biltmore”
Reviews.Author: leclaire68
Reviews.Content: The Millennium Biltmore has had plenty of reviews on TripAdvisor ... and those reviews have been quite mixed. I'm not sure I've ever seen a property with so many high reviews right after or before low reviews. I was intrigued and decided to check this property out for myself. I stayed one night during the week and booked a special rate, which also meant that my expectations were quite low for the type of room and service I thought I would receive. I chose to park at Pershing Square across Olive Street and pay $14.00 instead of the $30+ valet at the property itself. Parking at Pershing Square was very convenient (ride the escalator up to the ground level and walk across the crosswalk to the hotel) and also appeared to be quite safe. Security there is very present. Check-in was not only quick and efficient, but also quite friendly. I'm a firm believer that you reap what you sow, especially in large properties that see a constant stream of travelers, many of whom are less than patient. I greeted the front desk clerk with a smile and was treated with a kind, professional demeanor in return. Others have reported problems in this area, but I can honestly say that I saw no issue here. The bellman was also helpful when I asked about parking safety at Pershing Square. The location was perfect for my needs, in the heart of downtown and close to the 101 with easy access to other freeways. My room didn't have the best view, but again ... this was a special rate room. Room 329, though, did have a king sized bed, windows that let in plenty of light, and a headboard that was made up of substantial columns rising to the ceiling ... quite different than that of other photos posted by other reviewers on TripAdvisor. The carpet was in fine shape, the bathroom was in decent shape, and the room was appointed nicely. This is a historic property and one needs to keep that in mind when staying here. It is meant to have some "old world" charm. It does and I think it carries that off fairly nicely. "Old world charm" doesn't necessitate using cheap sheets and bed coverings, though. Millennium should be ashamed of themselves for keeping very low end linens in this property. That's such an easy thing to update and such an important part of an overall stay. The mattress, too, is absolutely sub-par. I've had better beds and linens in Holiday Inns and Travelodges. That charm requires a certain amount of maintenance, too. The Biltmore could stand some maintenance in spots: mouldings chipped, scuffs along the baseboards, chipping paint on the window panes. Another item that the staff really needs to pay better attention to is the amount of catering/room service items left in the hallways. I was amazed at the sheer volume of items outside doors as I walked to my room ... glasses, trays, half-eaten meals, etc. Most, if not all of it stayed there for the duration of my 1-night visit. Overall, I think many of the lower reviews for this property have been too harsh. I consider myself to have high standards for hotel accommodations and I would definitely stay at the Biltmore again.

Reviews.Title: “close to all attractions”
Reviews.Author: Ria_K
Reviews.Content: We stayed there during August 2007 and found that it was a good central place to stay for a tourist looking to see LA. We were able to visit universal studios,Beverly hills/Rodeo Drive, Malibu and Pacific coast highway,mullholand drive and venice/santa monica beach all withing good range from the hotel.We were also lucky to see a lot of film/video shootings in downtown area.it seems they do a lot of those around the hotel in downtown. Save money by --- 1) Parking at the hotel is expensive $32 !! So try Parking in the underground garage located on S. Olive St which is across the street from the rear entrance of the hotel.It costs just $14 for overnight parking and on weekends even cheaper $12 2) Eating at Subway ,Quiznos or Dominos(on S olive street right behind the hotel) all located within walking distance from the hotel. One complaint we had was the bathroom smelled horrible like there was mould growing but other that that the stay was good and felt very safe walking at night

Reviews.Title: “The rudest hotel staff”
Reviews.Author: holmes97
Reviews.Content: All staff we encountered were extremely rude - especially the concierge. Nobody at this hotel speaks English - so you can't get directions to any of the hotel amenities. And, if they do speak English - they don't know anything. Everything at this hotel is extremely over priced - from the $32 parking to the $2.25 drinks in the vending machines. The hotel website says it has a "continental breakfast" - this is not a complimentary breakfast. A breakfast of outmeal and a bagel will cost you $36.00. And, to access the fitness center and pool - you have to walk from the elevator through the main lobby and down a set of stairs.

Reviews.Title: “disgusting and horrible despite history”
Reviews.Author: moritzfamily
Reviews.Content: first, it took an hour to check into our rooms. i have a family of six. we asked for two rooms next to each other. this was impossible. second. it took hours for them to deliver our bags. literally hours. maybe i didn't tip them enough on my way in for the $32/day parking. next, and my biggest complaint for such a historical hotel, the rooms were dark and appeared to have never been cleaned. the bathroom tiles were tainted black and there were CIGARETTE BUTTS in the corner of a non-smoking room. on top of that, the road noise reached all the way up to the ninth floor and i couldn't fall a sleep because of a party being held in or around the hotel until 2am. i would never recommend this hotel. EVER. unless yyou just want to take a picture in the beautiful lobby.

Reviews.Title: “Overall, a good experience”
Reviews.Author: kingcocopuff
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Millenium Biltmore for 4 nights while in LA for a wedding and really enjoyed the hotel. We were fortunate enough to get a nice big room (we booked through [--], so it was up for grabs), and really enjoyed the beautiful decor and fabulous lobby and corridors. The cognac bar was a great place to meet friends and sip wine. I would agree with some of the reviews that the staff is not the most charming you have ever seen. You feel a bit like another faceless guest at times. But with the exception of one waiter at the hotel restaurant, the staff was efficient and helpful. The area around the hotel had some things of interest. You are a block away from the Downtown Library that had a great art exposition going at the time. Lots of outdoor art around the many skyscraping buildings too. Having a car is almost essencial though if you want to see anything other than a few blocks away from the hotel. It is quite empty after 5pm and deserted on the weekends.

Reviews.Title: “A balanced picture of the Biltmore”
Reviews.Author: pneyu
Reviews.Content: I'm writing this review to dispel some of the complaints about this hotel. First of all, this is in downtown Los Angeles, where there are homeless people, but I, as a female, never felt threatened by the surroundings. If you're concerned about the neighborhood, ask the hotel staff for tips and other guidelines on where to go. Another fact of visiting Los Angeles: You need a car. Downtown LA, like many other business centers, empties out after the workday, so your options might be limited. Yes, the rooms are relatively small, as are the bathrooms. Also, my bathroom showed tiny signs of neglect, but you had to look very hard to see it. We never felt penned in, and the AC was strong and cool that broiling SoCal weekend. However, the staff was responsive, and the lobby is indeed gorgeous. If you don't like the hotel restaurant, check out the many fine dining establishments now commonplace in downtown LA. Need a car? There's an Enterprise office across the street. There's a lot of potential around the Biltmore. Overall, though, the Biltmore was fine. It definitely wasn't a four-star hotel, and you're likely best off booking it through Priceline or Hotwire. Just don't let the bad reviews scare you away.

Reviews.Title: “Horrible!”
Reviews.Author: SiameseKitty
Reviews.Content: I paid an arm and a leg to stay here, and it was not worth it at all! I was so disappointed because from the outside and from the Internet photos, the Biltmore still looks grand and luxurious. In reality, it is subpar. The bed was a joke - thin and bouncy mattress and thin pillows. The linens made me itch a few minutes after sitting on them. All in all, the hotel is a little creepy. It has not been kept up. The rooms are dated (and not in a good, historic way) with small TVs and little counter space for your stuff. Parking is $36 a day, which is just outrageous. I looked all over the hotel's website to find out how much it would cost and could not find the price listed anywhere - now I see why. Other 4-star downtown hotels charge $25/day. The valets drive your car off to a distant parking lot somewhere downtown, so when you are waiting to get it back you are left standing and waiting for a v-e-r-y long time. I was so appalled I didn't even sleep here. I just left after a few hours and stayed somewhere else.

Reviews.Title: “Loved the architecture in this grand hotel!”
Reviews.Author: lizzieAustralia
Reviews.Content: I stayed at this hotel for 3 days with my husband and two teenagers. The hotel's decor was beautiful a reminder of the extravegant and luxurious hotels of the past. Upon arrival cherry coated chocolates were in our room with a personalised welcome letter. The main hotel restaurant Smiraldi's service was excellent as was the food. Definately the best al a carte meal I had in America. The waiters were extremely friendly and very professional. I would definately recommend this hotel to anyone wanting to experience the charm of a grand old hotel. Lizzie Australia

Reviews.Title: “amazing old hotel”
Reviews.Author: PassportStamps17
Reviews.Content: The entire building is unbelieveable. It's really ornate, like a palace. It was built almost 100 years ago, and they sure don't make hotels like this anymore. It's a little pricy, but for a downtown LA location with this much historical appeal, it's worth the splurge.

Reviews.Title: “Better Then Expected”
Reviews.Author: merpati2929
Reviews.Content: I recently stayed at the Millenium Biltmore evening of July 25th as I needed a place in the Los Angeles area without having to drive back out to Riverside for the evening. I was slightly concerned about the hotel in reading reviews here but after staying it was not as bad as I had feared. I arrived around 7pm on the evening of the 25th and was quickly helped with the bellman and the car was whisked away within seconds of it being unloaded. There was no wait at check-in which was polite and professional and the bellman literally followed us to the room with my friend and I with the only exception him taking the service elevator while we took the public one even though we both met up on the 8th floor at the same time. He quickly showed us to our room and unloaded all of our bags as my friend had quite the shopping trip on Rodeo Dr. earlier in the day and asked if we needed anything additional and even offered to fill our ice bucket which I thought was a nice touch. As we planned to go out later in the evening I called ahead for the valet to get the car ready and by the time we walked down after the call which was approx 10 minutes the car was ready and waiting for us. As stated in previous posts with it being an older holtel the rooms vary in size but the room I was located in was quite large and maybe even a bit too large with the furniture that was in the room. I do believe the room could use a bit of an upgrade in terms of bedding but the rest of the furniture seemed plentiful and there were plenty of both electrical outlets in the room for all of the stylist products of my friend to use. While the view of the room wasn't much you could see parts of Olive St which is better then most buildings which are smaller in size in crowded downtowns. Check-out was fast and efficent and once again I called down to have the valet get the car ready ahead of time and this time it was only about 5 minutes after I left the room and the car was ready and waiting once again. Overall the staff were professional and helpful with my only hesitation staying there again the aging beds and linens which could definately use an upgrade to bring them up to the 4* standard.

Reviews.Title: “Terrible Service”
Reviews.Author: wanderluster37
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the Biltmore on our wedding night. We booked this as a special treat to ourselves because we could not afford a honeymoon since we are both graduate students. Since we are both history buffs, we booked the Biltmore for its historical value and it seemed like the closest we could get to European grandeur without having to go to Europe (or Vegas, heaven forbid). Like others have stated, the entrance of the hotel is spectacular and the pictures speak for themselves. We booked a standard room but we were hoping to get a free room upgrade as most similar-class hotels provide this service for new bride and grooms. In fact, nearly all of our friends received free room upgrades and complimentary champagne and strawberries on their wedding nights in similar hotels in the area such as the hilton, westin, intercontinental, and the hyatt. We walked in with our full wedding attire and received many congratulations from random people. However, we were only met with rudeness with the concierge. The service was curt, there was no mention of congratulation, and when we asked if any kind of upgrades or services were available, the front desk person seemed appalled that we should even ask. When we mentioned our friends who had received this service at the Omni recently, they said, "Well then maybe you should have booked at the Omni." We were not expecting or demanding any kind of upgrade; we just inquired based upon the experiences of our other married friends. The fact that we were rebuffed in such a rude way was a major sore spot on our wedding night. The room we did end up staying in was almost offensive for the price we paid- we have even stayed in nicer hostels in Europe for a fraction of the price. My husband felt sorry that we had to spend our wedding night like this and we were very close to getting another room at the Bonaventure just down the street. We have stayed in their rooms and although they are small, the furnishings and decor are up to par with a 4 star hotel. We even called the Bonaventure from our Biltmore hotel room to inquire about room availabilities, and when we asked about services for new bride and grooms, the concierge replied professionally and guaranteed that yes, the Bonaventure always provides room upgrades for bride and grooms based on room availability, and we would have definitely received a suite if we had booked that evening. We ultimately decided not to book since we were so exhausted from the wedding and we didn't want to have to pay another $35 for valet parking on top of a wasted hotel night fee. The grand days of the BIltmore are certainly behind it. Judging by the service, you can tell that the hotel is struggling as it cannot keep up with its competitors in standard measures of hospitality. Downtown Los Angeles is rapidly developing and ironically, the once swanky and fashionable Biltmore will not be able to keep up with its gentrifying surroundings.

Reviews.Title: “Gorgeous and delightful”
Reviews.Author: ColoradoTripfan
Reviews.Content: Arrived at the hotel and it looked like the palaces in Europe with incredible ceilings. The halls were bright and clean. The surprise was that even though we booked on hotwire, we were upgraded to a suite with a lovely king bed, walk in closet, and separate sitting room with sofa and dining table. Only downside was that the room was not as soundproofed as it could have been. Traffic noise was audible, though not so bad that it prevented sleep.

Reviews.Title: “Classy old girl”
Reviews.Author: MrR0ng
Reviews.Content: The Millennium Biltmore was a beautiful old hotel. The public areas were gorgeous. The old girl definitely had a sense of history about her. I especially enjoyed the work out facility and pool. I felt like I was working out in the 40's. Really fun. The room was quite nice, large and well apportioned. I was able to get wireless in my room, which worked quite well. Very convenient to shopping and dining. I did have difficulty finding the concierge staff. As a former conicerge, I often depend upon concierge to ensure that I have a good stay. The concierge staff were hard to find. They alternate betweee being upstairs in the lounge, and downstairs on the desk. Overall, a great stay.

Reviews.Title: “Terrible Hotel For The Money”
Reviews.Author: JaySFBayArea
Reviews.Content: The Good: I love Downtown LA and there is much to do with Staples Center, good public transit (subway ) to Long Beach, great restaurants, and Dodger Stadium is just a short drive away. I stay in LA about every other month for work and always have a great time. Did I mention I love staying in Los Angeles. The hotel lobby and bar are absolutely beautiful I couldn't wait to get to my room The Bad: The rooms are not acceptable, I actually thought seriously about going to a different hotel! Luckily my wife was not with me because I doubt that she would have stayed. The rooms have beds and linens that must be 20 years old. Everything looked tired and dirty. The TV is the same 13 inch TV I had in my kitchen 25 years ago. I asked an employee if he had ever eaten at the sushi restaurant or if he had ever heard anything. He said he wouldn't eat there as he noted that if smelled really fish at times and he had heard bad things. I have stayed at the competition; Bonaventure, Marriott, Wilshire Grand and would gladly have stayed at any of them, although I do not ecommend the Wilshire. The Bonventure is a good deal and kind of neat to hang out in and around, just remember none are modern mavels.

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel for Low Price”
Reviews.Author: n23ramesh
Reviews.Content: My stay in this exquisite hotel became a life time memory. Staying in this hotel is like staying in a palace; however, I feel this hotel is lacking in good marketing. The price of this hotel is worth far more than what is being asked. People would be more than willing to pay more if few things were included in asking price such as parking, internet, refregerators, microwaves and more up to date TV sets. I feel price for this hotel room is far below what it should be..I will definately stay in this hotel again..

Reviews.Title: “For the price, it couldn't be better!”
Reviews.Author: blueskyholiday
Reviews.Content: My boyfriend and I stayed a night at the Millenium Hilton on a short stay in Los Angeles for the Police Concert at Dodger Stadium. I booked through Expedia, and my rate for a Saturday night was only $150 including taxes and fees. Rare for an upscale hotel these days, especially in a large city. We recently paid the same price for a fleebag motel in Monterey. Pros: * Amazing public spaces. I felt like I was transported to the glamour days of Hollywood past. Felt like a grand old New York style hotel. * Great bar. Not the sports bar, but the main bar attached to the lobby -- was gorgeous. Drinks however, were expensive. My Appletini was $14!! Free nuts though. * Room was charming. High ceilings, nice moulding, bed was comfortable and room was quiet. Who cares that the tv was a bit small...we were not there to watch the tube. *Easy to find. * Neighborhood is not 'scary' like other people have reported. It's just in a business district so there's not a lot going on at night. You'll need to drive if you want nightlife, unless of course you walk over to the Standard Hotel's roof top bar / club which is great. CONS: * Sports bar: ech. Dark, dingy, did not serve late night food. Actually it was really difficult to find late night eats besides the room service menu. * Expensive valet parking at $32 per stay. Also it was very crowded and there was an air of confusion where you drive up. Your car is whisked away before you even know what's going on. Make sure you have all your things with you when you exit your vehicle, I heard it was very difficult to retrieve items after the car has been parked. ************************** We didn't visit the pool which I would have liked to comment on but the pictures look amazing. All in all, very worth the money. We'll be back. Oh...one more thing, Expedia gives it a 3 and a half star rating (hotel class, I believe, not based on reviews) -- not 4 stars as reported on this website. I would have to agree with the 3.5 star rating as it could be use a little TLC.

Reviews.Title: “It's a wonderful experience in everyway - not in Kansas anymore”
Reviews.Author: digrace
Reviews.Content: To all of those who are insulting this hotel and the location I would have to disagree. I grew up in Kansas so I am no city slicker but I don't see ANY homeless people around this hotel. The streets are clean and safe. I now live in San Francisco and it is much more intimidating. The hotel is lovely and has good service. Furthermore, what do you want for a 3 1/2 star? The rate is $129 per night and parking is what it is. I can't believe the way some people are so self serving that they'd ruin a great experience and price for an average income working American to see a great historic architectural place. It has great restaurants everywhere and I walked the streets last night a 11pm with no problems. It aint the Four Seasons but overall it is the best hotel in downtown LA...

Reviews.Title: “great to experience the Biltmore”
Reviews.Author: RoyalYorkHotel
Reviews.Content: This is a perfect hotel for those interested in the grandeur of the past. The housekeeping service was quick, clean and efficient. Tea was lovely, except the server was not very engaged. On the other hand, the bartender in the lounge was outstanding. Terrific stories of the past. If you are looking for flat screen tvs and sleek duvets with trendy touches-this is not the place. But if you love ambiance and garndeur in public spaces...time to check in.

Reviews.Title: “4 stars!!! Loved the location, history, service and grandeur of the Biltmore”
Reviews.Author: ForensicAubs
Reviews.Content: I was sceptical after reading some of the reviews but took a shot anyway. I stayed 3 nights at the Millenium Biltmore in LA. My friend and I were in LA with the sole purpose of the trip to go on the Price is Right before Bob Barker retired. The hotel was a bit difficult to find even with GPS in the rent a car. It was not marked well and there is only one entrance to the valet parking structure. When you walk in the front lobby your breathe is taken away by the shear glamour of the hotel. After checking in and tkaing photos we were handed an 11 page list of all the films and television shows that were filmed there with the most recent being Dreamgirls, Mr. Deeds, Italian Job, etc. Hollywood apparently knows what type of grandeur this hotel offers. Anywhere in the hotel you felt as though you were among royalty and that old souls had walked the halls and stayed in the rooms. The Academy Awards were also held here and the Oscar statue was created on a cocktail napkin as well. We had a junior suite and when I called to check my reservation I asked if there was a fridge in the room and was assured there would be. However upon arrival there was not one in our suite. There was a gentleman, Mike, who was inspecting the fire sprinklers and I mentioned it to him, within 5 minutes I had a fridge in the room. Teh shower pressure was immaculate in our room although the fixtures were old, but ecclectic. We only ate at the Sports Bar which was good, Nachos and chicken sandwich. We tried to have Sushi delivered to our room but were told we had to pick it up, even though the restaruant was in the hotel. Teh sushi was expensive and we ended up going to Nobou in Malibu which was excellent. We opted for room service instead. The meal was excellent and hit the spot. We did use the Business center where internet use was quite expensive and printing was $1.99 per page. We were able to sneak into one of the main ball rooms as my friend saw a man carrying a table out of one of them. He turned the lights on for us and we took pictures of this beautiful room. We also went to the indoor Roman pool, spa and sauna as it was shown in the movie Cruel Intentions. We only went in the spa and sauna which were nice. There were workout facilites we did not use, but there were quite a few people partaking. The location was awesome too, we drove around for 3 days and only went 150 miles as the Price is Right and the Farmer's Market was only 10 miles away as well as Hollywood and Malibu, and LAX. All staff was helpful and courteous. We really enjoyed the old world charm this hotel offers and reccommend it to anyone, although I don't know that kids would enjoy it as much as we did. The only real complaint I had was the price of parking @ $32 per night and you could only valet. I would rather it be included in the price of the room and charged to all guests.

Reviews.Title: “Millenium Biltmore is a real treat”
Reviews.Author: zoobie
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Millenium Biltmore in February 2007 as we got an amazing deal and it was pure luxury. The lobby is beautiful, the cocktail bar is old time charm itself and all of our rooms were clean and spacious with huge TV's and coffee making facilities. There is also a Sports Bar within the hotel which was lots of fun. On the way to the pool, there are black & white photos of classic film stars from the hotel's OSCAR hosting days (which are slightly reminisent of The Shining to be honest!) which is great movie history! Fab hotel, well worth a visit even if you are not staying there!

Reviews.Title: “Great, classic meeting space, classically outdated rooms”
Reviews.Author: markotoole
Reviews.Content: The Biltmore really feels like LA of old. The common space, lobbies and meeting facilities are dramatic, beautiful and filled with history. Book your meeting there and you'll be happy. The meeting rooms once hosted the Academy Awards and other star-filled functions and they look as good today as they must have 70 years ago. The rooms are another story. Open your wardrobe and find what looks like a 20-year old small TV. Sheets and blankets are thin and old. Bathrooms are functional but small. The room itself is large and the bed moderately comfortable. Food is just OK. As it's an old hotel, outlets are at a premium, especially if you have a laptop, Blackberry, iPod, etc. to plug in. I got a good rate of $161 from Expedia. That's fair for this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent Choice”
Reviews.Author: cfopro
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed at the Millennium Biltmore over Memorial Day weekend. We initially went with the hotel based on a great deal on Expedia and hoped for the best. Right from our arrival, things went great. We were greeted warmly at check-in and we were informed we were being upgraded to a Junior Suite. The room was huge and, while not super modern, it was immaculate. We were also given vouchers for free breakfast for two mornings and a round of drinks at the hotel bar, to compensate for some minor remodeling going on that weekend (which didn't effect the quality of our stay one bit). The hotel itself is a gorgeous throwback to old L.A. The place has a ton of history and character, while still having all of the basic amentities needed in this modern world (i.e. high speed internet, business center, indoor pool, gym, etc.). It is centrally located and a good base for exploring Los Angeles. Finally, I highly recommend the martinis on offer at the Gallery Bar.

Reviews.Title: “Okay at best”
Reviews.Author: panewsgal
Reviews.Content: I was at the Biltmore Millennium for a conference earlier this month, and I have to agree with the majority of the previous posters. I travel quite a bit for business, and at this hotel, I feel it's all about the lobby and public areas and the guest rooms are sadly overlooked. When I arrived, I was definitely impressed. The lobby and front desk areas are truly stunning. Front desk clerk tried to "upgrade" me at check in (for a $50/night fee). I declined. However, I have to say my room was large when I stepped in - I was one of the lucky ones at my conference - other people's rooms were half the size of mine. No matter - as the PR/Marketing person for the hotel stated, it's an old property - and I can definitely understand the room variations in older hotels. What I can't understand, however, is the lack of quality in everything *inside* those guest rooms - small or large. Sheets were thin and paper-like, the pillows were like burlap sacks, the comforter was ratty, and bathroom amenities (shampoos, soaps, etc.) were never replaced during my entire stay even though I used them. In fact, one day the maid knocked a lampshade off the lamp when making the bed, and even though she was back to the room two additional nights - it was never fixed. What ticked me off though was the way the hotel nickel-and-dimed. I understand it's a high business hotel, and the thought process is that people are on expense accounts - and who cares what things cost?? Wrong. Those days are over - I have strict budgets I need to adhere to when I travel for business, and I don't appreciate a $6 charge to print out my boarding passes for my flight (grand total of time in the business center - 3 minutes). The hotel advertises hi speed internet in public areas and guest rooms - but be aware, it's certainly not *complimentary*.. The food was very good at my conference, however, and the meeting rooms, while a little chilly (but what meeting rooms aren't?), were beautiful and the ballrooms extraordinary. Staff was always pleasant and helpful I do agree with other posters, however, that the hotel is not the best location-wise for tourists at all, and while I didn't feel *unsafe* in the neighborhood, it did get a little seedy at night. So once the renovations are complete, I think this would be a fine property for your event or for business meetings. Tourists, however, reconsider.

Reviews.Title: “Grand hotel that has seen better days”
Reviews.Author: Blaize76
Reviews.Content: I spent four nights at this Biltmore and have to say that the lobby and meeting rooms were impressive and opulent in the old world Hollywood way. The staff was attentive, polite and professional, however the rooms are in serious need of an update. The beds and pillows were very hard. The comforter reminded me of something I have seen in budget hotels. The restaurant and room service was extremely overpriced! I ate at the restaurant three different times and the service was SLOW and the food exceptionally overpriced. If you enjoy being a part of a historic hotel, then I would suggest a night here, however if you are looking for comfort and luxury, look somewhere else.

Reviews.Title: “Nice staff, avg rooms, terrible neighbourhood”
Reviews.Author: josiehVancouver
Reviews.Content: The staff members were very helpful and the common areas were quite beautiful - lovely high ceilings and very well-kept. However, the room I stayed in (476) was quite small, tired looking and had a view of a brick wall. The linens were old and not luxurious by any means. The neighbourhood around the hotel is pretty sketchy and there's not much to do, particularly on the weekends. Even the Starbucks close to the hotel is closed on Sundays. I would not stay in downtown LA again. Next time I have meetings in downtown LA, I would stay in Santa Monica or Beverly Hills and rent a car.

Reviews.Title: “Not so much...”
Reviews.Author: AntoniaTempe
Reviews.Content: I just returned from a 4-day stay at this hotel. The lobby and meeting rooms are quite lovely -- they have an old Hollywood feel. However, the rooms are in need of a serious update. The rooms are large, but very dreary. The window overlooked a brick wall, so there was hardly a chance for any sunlight. The sheets were very low quality, the bedspread was dingy, the shower head had low water flow, the base of the vanity was some kind of painted plywood...I could go on and on. The location is good only if you have a business meeting in downtown. It's just not convenient to much else that tourists would like to see. Also, I just didn't feel that safe walking around on the weekend or in the evening.

Reviews.Title: “Out of Place, or what!”
Reviews.Author: SteveBishop.
Reviews.Content: Lovely looking Hotel with very good rooms and facilities. There is plenty to do on site as the gym, pool and steam rooms are all available to guests. We have no complaints about the facilities at this historic Hotel. We are working class people and the booking was a treat to ourselves and we did feel a little out of place. Some of the staff were less than polite to us and asking questions was a problem to a couple of them on a couple of occasions. I guess we didn't fit the bill of the kind of customer they expect. Having said that, Bar, Restaurant and Coffee Bar staff were without criticism. They were fine polite and helpful at all times. The area around the Hotel is not safe after dark and at weekends it dies as all the surrounding offices are empty. We went out to look around on our first day and found two blocks from the Hotel to be intimidating and this is just off of the Jewelery District, so an easy mistake to make. We were here for 4 days only and will not be returning. If you are going to LA for the first time, then look at Santa Monica, Anaheim and Pasadena as alternative places to stay. They are tourist friendly and near to all you will need to do whilst in LA. Avoid the Downtown at all costs. Not only for your safety, but just for strolling out at night to find things to do.

Reviews.Title: “Millenium Biltmore - Basic and Overpriced!”
Reviews.Author: skygirlIreland
Reviews.Content: Myself and my boyfriend stayed here for 5 nights in October 2006. On arrival, we were greeted in a friendly and efficient manner and directed to our room. The hotel lobby and all the public areas were fantastic. Not exactly my style hotel, I'm more into contemporary decor but the public areas in this hotel looked fantastic with their traditional decor. Once we entered the corridor from the lift though, we noticed that the standard had dropped dramatically. Instead of looking fresh like the lobby, the corridor looked very dated and in need of some redecoration. Once we entered the room, in this 4 star (?!) hotel, we were not too pleased at all. It was grubby in fact. I moved a chair towards the wall to make a bit more space and there were crumbs from the previous guests there which were obviously not cleaned properly. The room was dark, the bathroom was completely outdated, with dirty looking old tiles and the wooden panelling was painted white a long time ago but was now a dirty yellowy colour. Nothing special about this bathroom at all. I wasn't impressed. I was going to complain and ask to change rooms but I decided maybe that I was just expecting too much and that if this room was like this then all of them probably would. Later then we lay on the bed with the intention of watching telly for a while. There was a large mahogony television/drawers unit a few feet away from the end of the bed but with the side of it facing the bed. We pulled out the sliding tray with the television on it as far as we could and swivelled it as far as we could but we still could not comfortably see the television from the bed. This was a very bad set up altogether. Mind you there was 2 chairs in front of the television unit so perhaps you're only meant to watch television from there?! The concierge though, was very helpful, he helped us to organise a rental car and a day trip to Disneyland, he was a brilliant help to us I must say this. On our first morning, we went for breakfast in the hotels restaurant (we mistakenly thought it was included in the price - our fault). We walked in and it seemed to be a bit of a help yourself/we'll take your order at the table set up, so as the waiters were staring at us (but not approaching to explain the routine) we felt under pressure to just do something. So we took a seat at a free table. The waiter then approached and asked if he could take our order, I just wanted a bowl of Frosties and a slice of toast and my boyfriend ordered an omlette. I got the feeling from the waiter that we must have been doing something wrong with the ordering, and caused him some inconvenience but he never took the time to explain what we were supposed to do therefore how could we rectify this? As a result of whatever we did wrong?? the waiter proceded to be quite rude and abrupt to us throughout serving us. He nearly cut me with a look when I asked for a 2nd glass of orange juice. Next thing shock horror, the bill arrived for the breakfast! You won't believe the price. 7 dollars plus tax for a small bowl of Frosties, 5 dollars plus tax for ONE slice of toast with butter, 3 dollars each for the small glasses of orange juice and 15 dollars for an omlette served with a few breakfast potatoes. When we queried the waiter politely as to whether or not breakfast was included he stomped off to check with reception, he came back and said that it wasn't so we didn't argue and took the bill. He left us momentarily while we organised the money. The total bill including tax was around 38 dollars so we put 40 dollars in the bill booklet and as we stood to leave the waiter practically ran over to our table and picked up the bill booklet, in front of us, he rudely opened the bill, acknowledged the 40 dollars and threw his eyes to heaven with a loud "tut" because clearly he didn't think that 2 dollars was enough of a tip for making people feel uncomfortable and being rude right throughout our service. The Sports Bar in the hotel was very dingy and really undesirable but we ate there the first night, the food was only ok and a homeless person managed to come in and hassle us for a tip while we were eating. Location-wise, the hotel was only ok too. We rented a car for a day or two which was great and also the metro stop was only around the corner which brought you to most places easily enough but it was a bit of a trek out to Hollywood and Universal Studios. The gym and swimming pool were very poor as well unfortunatlely and we didn't feel the urge to use these facilities once we saw them. Unfortunately, for the price we paid for the grubby accomodation and especially the measly overpriced breakfast, and the rudeness of that waiter, the dirt of the Sports Bar, it was just enough for me to say that for your money you could probably get a better hotel in LA in possibly a better location. I honestly wouldn't recommend this hotel to anyone - especially tourists, maybe we had that look about us that they felt they could throw us in any old room and we'd be content because to be honest the hotel seems to hold a lot of business conferences etc during the day and the restaurant where we had breakfast seems to be a classy financial district type restaurant where professionals go for business meetings over dinner or something. They could do with concentrating on their accommodation though. Unless there was a different set of rooms for business guests, then I don't understand how they would stay in this hotel over night?!

Reviews.Title: “Enjoyed the Millenium!”
Reviews.Author: susiebee2002
Reviews.Content: My husband & I stayed two nights at the Millenium Biltmore in LA while waiting to board a cruise ship. It was our first time in LA and we thoroughly enjoyed both the hotel and the city. A car rental is a must though to get around and see everything. The hotel was so impressive - old and beautiful; very comfortable room and bed; wonderful restaurant; accomodating staff. Highly recommend it!

Reviews.Title: “Nice lobby, horrible rooms”
Reviews.Author: nedve18
Reviews.Content: I stayed one night ilast December with my family. The moment you arrive the hotel, yo see the beautiful lobby, but once you get the rooms, you want to leave the hotel. Even the service is really good, the rooms are extremely old, but not the old charm they appear they are. Try to find other hotel in downtown, this is not worth it.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful, reasonably priced old hotel”
Reviews.Author: penelope2007
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the Millenium Biltmore for a long weekend, and we really enjoyed it. The common areas are breathtaking -- the carved ceilings especially -- and the location is great. The rooms are nothing terribly special, but they are clean and spacious. For thevery reasonable price, I think this hotel is a great choice.

Reviews.Title: “Classic hotel even if the rooms aren't”
Reviews.Author: SCB_JR
Reviews.Content: Truely a classic, Grand Hotel as the public areas demonstrate. Rich wood, high ceilings and all of the flair and taste that does take you back to the early 20th century. But IT IS an old hotel with the rooms to match. We have stayed there 2X ... once in a standard room and then on the "Club" level. Both rooms were in need of a degree of "freshening" as the general furniture and decor was dated and worn. The Club level (a bit more $) did provide a nice sized, corner suite with plenty of light. Included with the level was an excellent breakfast offering ... juices, fresh fruit, yogart, assortments of fresh bakery goods, etc., which was well appreciated. They provided a similar "Happy Hour" of sorts early evening also. That was a nice touch. We MUCH prefered the Club level and would consider staying again. Service overall, was acceptable, not superior nor terrible. There are several very good restaurants within close walking distance if you choose. If you're looking for luxurious rooms and boutique surroundings, stay across the street at Checkers (have stayed there also) and visit the Biltmore's lobby but expect to pay serious cash for the difference.

Reviews.Title: “Has Class but also Flaws”
Reviews.Author: MisstheDogs
Reviews.Content: Arriving at the Biltmore and entering the lobby is impressive indeed. It is spacious and rather grand. A long hallway runs behind the lobby and contains restaurants, shops and convention room. The hotel has a good business location and is near the Dorothy Chandler Pavillion. When I went to check in, I had to wait for about 10 minutes because the entire computer system had crashed. However, after, that there way no wait and I was on my way to my room. It was unacceptable. First, the room looked like something out of the 1950s -- an older looking, low-level queen bed complete with a 1950s/1960s style cream bedspread and dust ruffle that didn't match, didn't fit, and was torn. There's good retro and bad retro; this was bad. The carpet was stained. The room was very, very small and very dark. The view was of a wall. The bathroom was tiny and poorly remodeled. There was one wing-back chair that looked incredibly uncomfortable. Also, the room was so small that you couldn't possibly sit in the chair and watch TV. TV was on the dresser. There was a desk with a desk chair. However, the desk was the only table in the room. There was no nightstand -- some weird heavy box-like object (like an overturned computer box) was lying on the floor right next to the bed with various wires attached to it. Not sure what it was or what it was for. But no bed light, no place to put anything if you lay in bed. I didn't see a clock. The only phone was on the desk -- not reachable from the bed. The worst part, however, was that there were huge stains on the cream-colored bedspread. At that point, I demanded a new room. I was upgraded to a "junior suite." Very large with separate sitting room, but the furniture was still somewhat dated and I couldn't fairly describe the suite as attractive or luxurious. The carpet was stained. Tiles were missing from the dressing area counter. The TVs (there were 2) were only 19" at best. The bathroom was ok but small and also a bit dated. Also, no mini-bar and no bottled water, coffee or tea. Not sure if there were vending machines but, other than tap water, nothing in the room to drink. Service was unremarkable -- neither great nor bad. Concierge was helpful. Checkout was slow -- there were 7 people in line and only one person to provide assistance. Room service (breakfast) was fine -- prompt and tasty. Had dinner in the Japanese restaurant; it was good as was the service there. Didn't make use of other hotel facilities. I get the impression that what room you end up with could mean the difference between a decent stay and an unsatisfactory one but am not sure what room or type of room you need to request. There is a club level -- didn't stay there but maybe it's better. Overall, my experience was merely okay (once I was in the second room). I've stayed in many nicer hotels for the same price and thus will probably look elsewhere when I return.

Reviews.Title: “Upscale Common Areas, Average Rooms, Good Price”
Reviews.Author: taprennoc
Reviews.Content: I have stayed at this hotel several times over the past year, and never been disappointed. First Impression is the lobby, ballroom hall, and the Bar are fantastic and reminiscent of old hollywood. It has a great gym also. The rooms are in need of an update of the bed linens to get them up to par with chains such as Hilton. The room itself was nice, the bathrooms are a bit small and cramped, and the tv's are very small. No wireless internet. 30.00 to park for guest which I think is outrageous. But if you book far enough in advance, the rates are very very good for such a beautiful hotel and its ammenities. I have never paid more than 150.00 a night, and for downtown LA that is a great rate. The Hilton across the street is close to 400.00 a night. The sports bar has pretty good food, or you can walk a block to McCormick & Schmidts as well. I would certainly recommend this hotel for busienss travelers, or even tourists should stay here at least once to check out the place.

Reviews.Title: “Movie Set Hotel”
Reviews.Author: turls
Reviews.Content: The Biltmore is kept in a very traditional manner-it is full of history and in this respect a fascinating hotel-it has been used in many many films and tv shows and I have recognised it in a few since we stayed there. It staged the Oscars in the 1930's, was JFK's campaign HQ and has lots of other claims to fame. It is still a well appointed hotel, we had a nice large comfortable room which was clean and well appointed. The windows are old and therefore noise and cold can be a problem. The location is also a bit of a problem if you arein LA as a tourist, it is quite a way to Hollywood Blvd fro example and the streets around the Biltmore at night are virtually empty, this can lead to it feeling a bit intimidating when walking back from the metro etc. We were lucky enough to be able to watch filming of 'Without a Trace' being done in the hotel, it was in a room just off from the lifts that used to be the reception in days gone by-it was interesting to see. If staying here it is definately worth speaking with a member of staff about the history of the place, they all seemed well educated on their workplace-from Al Capone, The Beatles to the victim of the Black Dahlia murder, they have all been there!

Reviews.Title: “Old School Charm”
Reviews.Author: highflyingirl
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Millenium Biltmore for business. It has a great location downtown and it is easy to get in and out of the parking/valet area. The Biltmore has "Old School" charm. I have attended several conferences at this hotel and all have gone very smoothly. The ballroom is beautiful. You can look at all of the old pictures of past events and celebrities. The first room that I was given at the time of check in was not good. I walked in to a strong mildew smell and the bottom of the comforter was stained. It was also very drafty and loud. The window was not sealed and there was a 1 inch gap between the top and bottom window. I asked to be moved and they put me into another room that was smaller but very cute, comfortable, and clean. Dinner room service was always prompt and the food was good (I didn't have breakfast at the hotel). The fitness center does not open until 6am, so for people that have to get going early that doesn't work. The fitness center does have a variety of weights and machines and a cool indoor lap pool. The front staff was friendly and efficient.

Reviews.Title: “Look, but don't stay.”
Reviews.Author: DRace
Reviews.Content: This hotel exudes the golden age of Hollywood. The lobby and common areas are nothing short of spectacular. Be sure to look at all the wonderful photographs and memorabilia. I strongly suggest a visit for a drink or a walk-through, but do not recommend an overnight stay. The elegance ends when you get to your room. The rooms are comparable to the cheapest motels -- cheap bedspreads and linens, bad furniture, terrible art, etc. There is no mini-bar and the coffe pot is a one cup, paper no less, model. The bathrooms are even worse. The attempts to bring them up to date failed miserably. Instead of capturing the era, they are a pitiful mix of styles and a terrible use of space. Add to that, that the shower had no water pressure and tepid water on both mornings of my stay. And the worst is that no one has made any attempt to soundproof or at least diminish the traffic noise. I was on the 7th floor and would have sworn my window was open. The old original windows are in place and the plantation shutters (with some broken pieces) did nothing to muffle the noise. Neither did the drapes. While some older hotels have fans in the AC system that can be turned on high to muffle street sounds, this one did not, so you were stuck with noise far worse than any I have heard in NYC. After reading this, I changed my review to terrible, from okay. The lobby and beauty of the structure, just can't make up for the woeful inadequacies of a hotel that bills itself as a luxury property. There was nothing luxurious about the accommodations.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful lobby, ballrooms. Rooms aren't that great unless your royalty.”
Reviews.Author: JamieJam
Reviews.Content: Stayed during Christmas 2006. Hotel may be great to see on a Historic tour of L.A. and if your an old Hollywood buff and want too see where 1930s Academy Awards were held. Rooms are lackluster and underkept in comparison to lobby and ballrooms. All ballrooms where locked up ( best part of hotel and they lock it up to guests!). I did sneal a peek one day at the Biltmore Bowl and the Crystal Ballroom, Beautiful! I just got lucky that day. A film crew where in and they unlocked it all for them. The resturant were bothered that a asked for my a.m. coffee in a to go cup, they told me they don't do that. Staff was cold, distant and security were plentiful and cold also. Hard to get people to smile around there. We had a room with two queen beds. Bathroom was the worst. Mold, old broken cheap fixtures, bathtub was never cleaned while we were there. Such a grand hotel but comes up very short on guestrooms. All the money must go to keeping lobby and ballrooms beautiful. So, it looks pretty online and the main entrance is, but if you like plush rooms and cleanliness this is not the hotel for you.

Reviews.Title: “I spent Christmas at the Biltmore ”
Reviews.Author: NEWPORTGUY
Reviews.Content: I just spent the Christmas holiday at the Biltmore. The hotel was decorated beautifully and was very calm and peaceful - as down town Los Angeles is very quiet on holiday weekends. The rooms are quite spacious and were very clean. Check-in/check-out was smooth. I would highly suggest the High Tea in the Rendevous Court and the Gallery Bar is a great people-watching spot. My only complaint would be dinner on Christmas Eve. We had the misfortune of encountering Esmerelda (hostess) at Smeraldi's restaraunt. With a total of 6 tables in the dining room, during the 8:00 hour, she insisted that all the many dozens of tables were booked for the evening and we would need to dine elsewhere. When I explained that we were guests at the hotel and the front desk had actually suggested Smeraldi's, she showed no concern - only when we asked to speak to the manager - all their reservations disappeared! Thankfully we had a great server, but the food was average at best. Other dining suggestions: across the street at Hilton Checkers and just down the street at the Westin Bonaventure,

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel, location not suitable for tourists”
Reviews.Author: tomruth78
Reviews.Content: We stayed here on 02 November 2006 for three nights. The hotel is beautiful in decor and the history of the place is interesting. Worth getting up early from the jet lag and having a walk around. The rooms are fine for an old hotel, the size of the room was adequate and yes the bathrooms are small, but what do you expect from an old hotel? We have stayed in brand new hotels with smaller bathrooms! The rooms were clean and serviced every day. We were in room 840 which looked out the side of the hotel. Noise was a bit of a problem with traffic but no more than stopping in a London hotel. If you are a light sleeper you might want to pack some earplugs. The reception staff were fine and the concierge was very helpful. The only problem with this hotel is its location. As we were only in LA for three nights we wanted to see all the sights. By being downtown it took a long time to get anywhere, even with the Metro. One option on the menu was a breakfast buffet for $20 + tax which is slightly steep compared to other hotels we stayed in, but there was plenty of choice. The service was fine though the waiters could have been a little friendlier. I would recommend anyone staying for business to stay here, but anyone going to LA for leisure to pick the location of their hotel wisely that is unless you want to stay in a hotel that is beautifully decorated and has a bit of Hollywood history and glamour.

Reviews.Title: “Fine Hotel @ Good Price”
Reviews.Author: dv8r
Reviews.Content: I stay in a lot of LA hotels, most way over rated and this one exceeded my expectations by far... I have seen some reviews complain that the place is run down, old or whatever, and actually I found it more than adequate for my needs. It had a classic feel and was like staying in a museum, what with all the old photos and history of the joint. The bar was not cheap, but the drinks were perfect and the staff more than accomodating. Would return ... wish I had more time to enjoy the place. The location is right on Pershing Square, and I used that proximity to try LA's new metro line to Hollywood. I ended up here happily via a random Priceline hotel search in the sub $100 range. I see that they charge almost double that regularly...

Reviews.Title: “Grand Old Hotel”
Reviews.Author: SthAussies
Reviews.Content: We recently stayed at the Biltmore for 3 nights. The staff were friendly when we arrived and the room clean and tidy with coffee and tea facilities. Two double beds and a small table and chair. The foyer, reception and lobby areas were impressive. On arrival there was a demonstration in Pershing Park which created noise when the window was open but overall the room was quiet and you couldn't hear your neighbours. We were pleased with the service and cleanliness of the hotel and it was great to stay in a hotel with history. The hotel shop was full of interesting photos and facts about the hotel. We would stay again if in Los Angeles.

Reviews.Title: “Grand Historic Biltmore”
Reviews.Author: hotelgirl111
Reviews.Content: The Biltmore is a beautiful historic deco hotel in downtown Los Angeles. I would DEFINITELY return if I was doing business in LA. I also recommend it to tourists who want to stay in the downtown area. It has gorgeous public spaces, and is a great hotel to get drinks in the lobby. It's fun to peek into ballrooms, and think of all the movie stars that have walked the halls. My room was nothing fancy. The hotel hasn't been redone in ages, and there is nothing spectacular about the amenities beyond the actual building. Even so, the bathroom was small, but with a great old showerhead that had incredible water pressure. Our morning breakfast was wonderful, on the 10th floor. It was some sort of corporate client perk, and it was one of the best continental breakfasts I've ever had. The fruit and yogurt cups were over the moon! Also a neat view from the top floor... The best thing about the Biltmore: THICK WALLS. This is a pre-war building, and it has the quietest rooms I've ever stayed in. You can just tell the hardware and construction is superior.

Reviews.Title: “A worldl of luxury”
Reviews.Author: coateseric
Reviews.Content: What a wonderfull experience. This large, character hotel situated in Downtown LA. The atmosphere and ombience of this classic hotel has to be experienced to believe. I had to double check what I had paid as I was sure it was too exepensive for me. BUT no A great hotel in a great location with loads and loads of history. We visited Hearst Castle 2 days before and this was like going back to Hearst Castle. YOU MUST VISIT TO BELIEVE

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Classy Hotel”
Reviews.Author: Traveling_Lady_OC
Reviews.Content: Please do not pay attention to those who would say negative things about the Biltmore, they obviously were expecting a new Hilton or something of the like. The Biltmore is a lovingly restored hotel, originally built in 1923. Decorative and classic, I enjoyed it from the moment I stepped foot inside. The staff is perfect, every need is quickly attended to. Checkin was a breeze, and that is not always easy when there is a gigantic wedding going on! We wandered around and looked at the banquet rooms which were beautifully restored with mouldings, beams, murals, carvings and the like. Absolutely beautiful works from the original muralist known as Smeraldi whose paintings are also in the Sistine Chapel. The restaurants are simply breathtaking in their beauty and the food is unparallleled. The High Tea in the Rendezvous Room is something you do not want to miss! Very good tea with lovely scones and goodies, excellent service and ambience. They make you feel like royalty! We had a room on the 7th floor, and the room was furnished nicely and well-cared for. It is obvious the hotel is older, there are still remnants of dumbwaiters, and other little bygone-era touches. But we loved the place and can't wait to return!

Reviews.Title: “Can't see what the problems are here???”
Reviews.Author: Ausboxer
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Millenuim Biltmore in September, from the 4th until the 8th, and thoroughly enjoyed my stay. The Lobbies and public areas are just beautiful, I felt like I was in Old-world Hollywood! My room was a great size - not at all small, we had two double beds and plenty of room to relax and spread out. The bathroom was more than adequate - large,even, and although was starting to show its age it was on the whole well maintained and clean. I found the staff to be pleasant and helpful, providing us with directions, and advice, and the valet staff were excellent. Many complain about the price of parking - welcome to big city holidays! Coming from Sydney, Australia - these prices are par for the course.. As far as location went, for us it was great, easy to get to all the major attractions by car, and the train was two blocks away.

Reviews.Title: “Unimpressed with the Biltmore”
Reviews.Author: cboer711
Reviews.Content: The Biltmore is an old beautiful hotel in downtown Los Angeles. However, the old portions of the hotel outweighed the beautiful parts. The lobby and accompanying area are quite well-done, it is interesting staying in a hotel that has hosted many 1950s award shows. It seems though that the rooms have not been redone since right before the 50s shows. We were surprised that the tv was color (the most modern feature in the room). I can appreciate historic hotels, but at some point the guest rooms need an update. The property is large and I figure this is the reason that the housekeeping did such a shabby job cleaning the room. Overall, we were disppointed especially having come from another historic hotel in Santa Monica that had done everything right. If you don't need to be in downtown LA for business, don't stay in downtown. However, if work brings you into the city look elsewhere for a quality hotel, the Biltmore missed the mark.

Reviews.Title: “If i could be there now!”
Reviews.Author: nicobaby
Reviews.Content: This is far more one of the best hotels I have stayed. I can not see how anyone was rate this bad. It is beautiful and everybody is so helpful. We only had one problem when the air stopped working in the room then we was upgraded for the same price. Everytime I show the pictures EVERYBODY comment on the room and pool area and we recommend to everyone no matter what state it is to stay at the blitmore and you can not go wrong. Yes there is a bit more homeless people than where I am from (GA) but they do not bother you and after stepping out of that hotel it just shows you just how blessed you are. All the attractions are good. Great Sate!

Reviews.Title: “Great Stay!”
Reviews.Author: Jabeka
Reviews.Content: Booked two rooms here for a concert overnight stay and was very impressed. The staff was friendly and helpful, was not put off in the least because of booking through PriceLine (which is sometimes the case.) Our rooms were clean and charming, the lobby was all the glamour we expected at the original sight of the Academy Awards, and our breakfast there was outstanding. Walking through the halls and taking in all of the historic photographs was as good as a visit to an entertainment history museum! We did not use the pool, but it is truly a work of deco art. I was somewhat worried about this booking after reading some negative TA reviews, but my stay was a positive one from start to finish. Which just means that while not everyone is going to be pleased, not everyone is going to end up having a bad experience either. I would highly recommend this hotel for a lovely step away from the typical city high rise hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Mixed feelingas about the Biltmore”
Reviews.Author: amrscotland
Reviews.Content: I have mixed feelings about the Biltmore. Lets start with the positve: the price - very good value especially if it includes breakfast. The buliding is very impressive - very grand and the rooms were clean and comfortable. The breakfast was excellent and attention from the waiters very good. We liked the location and used the nearby subway station at Pershing Square to get to Univeral Studios and Hollywood. The public transport is very cheap and efficient. We even got the bus to Santa Monica !! However there are some negatives: We arrived at 4.30pm after a flight from the UK. At first we were told there were no rooms available(despite booking and paying well in advance with a very reputable company in the UK). The receptionist then offered us 1 upgraded room on the Club floor (but not allowed to use the extra facilities on that floor) and were told to phone down at 8 pm to see if our other room was available. So 5 of us - 3 adults and 2 kids (aged 12 and 13) tried to get a bit of rest in a room with 2 double beds. We were lucky - a gentleman checking in at the same time was sent away despite having a reservation number. At 8pm we were advised that our room would not be available until 11pm!!! At this point we spoke to the manger and told him we were going for a meal and when we got back we wanted a room or another hotel. Half an hour later we had our 2nd room - albeit 2 floors below the other one. Because of this probem we did manage to get a late check out free of charge the day we left but only because we asked and it was given grudgingly. The receptionist seemed to think that 1 upgraded room was sufficient compensation. On that subject, the only difference I could see between the club rooms and the standard rooms was the decor, newspaper deliverd to the room and free bottled water! Rooms were clean and comfortable but in need of a little TLC - a bit worn in places and in need of an upgrade. Bath rooms are small even by British standards and definatley in need of an upgrade. Pool - not in use as under repair Location good but a lot of panhandlers about - no problems but may make some people uneasy. The probelms with check in didn't in the end spoil our stay but I would be wary about staying here again.

Reviews.Title: “Millenium Biltmore - an unfriendly place”
Reviews.Author: herren
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Biltmore from July 12th to the 15th 2006. As a family (my husband, myself and three children aged 4, 11 and 16) travelling from Australia, we'd just had 3 days at Disneyland staying at a hotel in Anaheim. When we moved from Anaheim to the Biltmore I immediately felt we didn't fit in there. The ladies at reception were extremely unfriendly and when we asked them a question it was answered extremely reluctantly. My husband and I had a drink in the gallery bar (the children were in the room watching TV) and the barman was also not very friendly. The concierge, a wonderful man called James, made up for the unfriendly staff with his charming and friendly manner and he gave us all sorts of helpful tips, such as the location of a market nearby where we could purchase fruit for the children (we bought 5 bananas for US 80 cents! wow! in Australia currently bananas cost about AU$2.50 each!!!) and advice on what sort of tour of LA we should go on. Yes the Biltmore is a beautiful and impressive hotel with a colourful history. However it's the first hotel I've stayed at where there was no bar fridge in the room - this costs an extra $10 per night! The pool, which the children were desperate to try out was not available the whole time we were there (!!! in the middle of summer!!!! Grrr!!!) The room was spacious and comfortable but overall I would not stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Glamour at the Biltmore Hotel”
Reviews.Author: NZ_Kate
Reviews.Content: If a dose of old fashioned gilt and glamour appeals, try the Millennium Biltmore Hotel in downtown LA. The original home of the Oscars, the Biltmore was extensively refurbished a few years ago. The rooms varied in size and mine looked into the somewhat gloomy inner courtyard, but even though you could tell they were old-fashioned rooms done up, it all worked. The decor was fitting for the style/age of the hotel and that's what gave the Biltmore an edge in our minds - none of this admittedly pleasant but characterless browns, beige and white of modern hotels. The staff were most helpful, we loved the lobby bar and would definitely go back again.

Reviews.Title: “I wouldn't pay to stay here”
Reviews.Author: Katze
Reviews.Content: I stayed here 2 nights for a meeting and am glad I didn't pay for it. The lobby and ballrooms are lovely, but it stops there. My room was small and dingy and the bathroom was gross. There was mold on the tiles and the bathtub didn't drain properly, so I ended up standing in a foot of water towards the end of my shower. I have to say the staff was not very good in regards to meeting logistics. There were AV problems, the staff took forever to get there, and it took a long time to get things straightened out. They did not speak English very well and did not seem to fully understand what they were doing. I would visit this hotel again to admire the lobby beauty but never pay to stay.

Reviews.Title: “DITTO "False Impressions"”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I agree completely with the previous author. I only wish I had the review before I booked the reservation. I ended up cutting my trip short by one day and spent my time hanging out at the Bonaventure instead.

Reviews.Title: “False Impressions”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: The hotel has a great historical background. I'm sure it was wonderful when it opened in 1923 but they need to make some major improvements. It is a nice place to visit but not to stay. The lobby and the rendezvous court are very nicely decorated however the rooms have a 2 star appeal to them. They were dirty and the curtains and bedsheets had stains on them. The bathroom was extremely small and half the size the size of the closet. No room to place toiletries. There was a piece of bacon on the floor upon our arrival and it remained in the same location until we departed. Although maintenance is poor, customer service is very good. Employees are very friendly. The $30 for valet however was not worth it. Overall I would not recommend this hotel to anyone. Beware of the pictures on the hotel website they can be deceiving!!!

Reviews.Title: “Good stay”
Reviews.Author: TravelToronto
Reviews.Content: I enjoyed my stay at the Millenium. The only thing I didn't like was its location.
