Basically, there is nothing near the hotel, shopping, restaurants, etc. At one night looking for a decent place to eat, I went to a seedy area with lots of homeless. Othetr than that, the hotel is nice and comfortable

Reviews.Title: “Parking Issues at Biltmore Millenium”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Service was good, decor interesting for Los Angeles, friendly stuff, lots of events and weddings taking place downstairs, good restaurant... But someone already noted - parking (a couple of years ago) was over 30 dollars overnight! And for over two hours! Including guests you invite over to dinner! I stayed in this hotel and invited some friends who live in town, and they got stuck with 33 dollar bills for parking their car in the hotel. Nobody walks in LA or uses public transportation, it is only driving. Downtown LA is not exactly a beautiful area, and not pedestrian friendly either. There is no place to park near by either... So... I think with the money this hotel charges for stay, parking for guests should be complimentary or reduced price, no more than 3 dollars. But 33!.. hmm

Reviews.Title: “Nothing better, fantastic”
Reviews.Author: rtgt
Reviews.Content: my wife and I and another couple were coming to LA for a conference at the end of April. I reserved the Biltmore before I started reading all the reviews. As you know the reviews are all over the map, from positive to negative. Well let this very conservative Canadian from Edmonton describe the Biltmore. First impression driving to the entrance was wow, they then let us check in at 12:00, 3 hours adhead of the posted check in time. Service was great. Both rooms were above average in size with great king size beds. Who cares if the bathrooms were a little small. Our rooms were in the 01-10 range and thus at the end of a very short hall, no noise what so ever. we were there for 6 nites and the staff became more than staff they became friends. The doormen and the bellmen were all fantastic. the Champs sports bar was friendly and the food good. the pool area was above average. the history of the hotel was nothing but amazing and the public areas were like nothing I had ever seen. The neighborhood??? I felt comfortable going for walks at 6 in the morning or 10 at nite. as far as the homeless, they are far more polite than the homeless I have met in other cities. More importantly if you take the time to talk to them you will realize that they are just like the rest of us. They were great and no reason to be afraid of them. They are also polite enough to say hello every day and remember you. All in all the Biltmore and the neighborhood were great. If some one wants to stay downtown this is the place to be, a nice easy 15 minute walk to the staples center or the convention center. the staff need to be commended for their positive attitudes and although I am not a world traveler, I would will out any hesitation at all recommend the Biltmore. I will be back, and I will recommend to all the people that I know who are going to LA. To the management and staff thanks for a wonderful experience.

Reviews.Title: “Shiny front - shabby back. Good for smokers.”
Reviews.Author: Paulgr
Reviews.Content: The brochures and website photos all laud the grand ballrooms and lobby. These are indeed magnificent but belie the rooms behind them. You can stay somewhere better and just walk in and look. At $USD185 a night we didn't expect to find our bathroom door off its hinges or the continuing struggle with room staff for such trivialities as providing more coffee satchets. The guy that fixed the door was resigned to the fact that he and his colleagues had a real job on their hands and told us we were lucky that we didn't have plumbing problems. Parking is very expensive and the valets (compulsory valet service) get surly if not tipped extravagantly. On the plus side - for all those smokers out there - the Biltmore's fire escape lobbies are not alarmed or monitored and open on to little balconies. Just perfect for that quiet smoke without having to get dressed and leave the hotel.

Reviews.Title: “An enjoyable historical experience”
Reviews.Author: mf4516
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed at the Biltmore for one night as part of a much-longer trip to LA and southern CA. A lot of tourists and business travelers go to the Biltmore because of its high-class reputation and historical significance; we were there as part of a self-guided architectural history walking tour (which I highly recommend BTW, check the LA Conservancy web site). The best feature of this hotel is its public areas ... make sure you allocate time to sit in the lobbies, have a look at the banquet rooms, have a drink at the martini bar (expensive but very romantic) and definitely swim in the beautiful Italian-tile pool. I think the hotel is aware of the popularity of its public areas; after I got dressed I took several pictures of the pool and at some point a security person showed up and looked me over (but left when I smiled and waved at him). The rooms were small but very clean and the bed was wonderful. Decor is classy but materials are somewhat old. The bathroom was very small but nicely tiled and worked well. We had a view of the interior air column of the hotel, but after walking around downtown LA I can't say that we would have benefitted much by an exterior view! The staff are very nice and polite but very busy (I get the impression that there are a lot of people checking in and out all the time). Internet is not free and parking is expensive. The neighborhood has improved a lot in the last decade-- we felt safe at night but there are a lot of disheveled, muttering people wandering about and occasionally panhandling in their polite, southern California style. Overall, I'd comment that this hotel is worth a stay for historical reasons and to experience the hotel itself, but I personally wouldn't recommend it for kids or for a long tourism experience outside of the downtown LA area.

Reviews.Title: “Why the complaining? ? Its just beautiful!!!”
Reviews.Author: Solemn-Angel
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the Biltmore for 4 nights in April, we had a lovely time. The hotel was so beautiful, every part of it was just amazing!! The staff were all lovely and too happy to help. We ate in the sports bar and also a californian restaurant (smereldis i think its name was) and they were both really yummy.. The sports bar was fun, the waitress was really lovely and even cheered on with us for the Lakers! The concierge was very friendly and helpful, it was great being able to cash travellers cheques at the hotel - and with no fee!! Our room was really lovely and spacious, i liked the old feel the hotel gave out. The pool, saunas, spa and gym areas were great - hubby had a swim and a spa and said both were terrific. The hotel is just amazing - stay there and you wont be disappointed! It was one of the highlights of our Californian holiday.

Reviews.Title: “Great Building - But !!”
Reviews.Author: carolpowell321
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Biltmore, which is Downtown, for 3 nights in April 2006 as part of our 25 th wedding anniversary 2 week trip to America. The biggest problem we encountered was the location. We were there over Good Friiday through to Sunday and with all the business's closed it was like a ghost town. As soon as we walked out of the hotel we were constantly approached by homeless people morning and afternoon. We decided not to go out after 1800 and although we still managed to go were we wanted did not get to go the bars or restaurants in the evening. I would certainly stay in annother part of LA. We did the City tour which was really what you have to do to see Hollywood etc. We also went out to Santa Monica which was more suitable for staying in and then touring the City. Conversations with locals backed up our view that Downtown is not a good place to be after 1800, whereas Santa Monica was. Getting back to the Hotel, i can't see it surviving and attracting tourists, it has great history and they are doing their best to keep it up to scratch, but it feels like a hotel without any sole and the staff need an update on customer service. I wa hoping for some recognition that we were on our 25th anniversary trip, however despite their promises to 'let me know' they never responded and did seem to have some superior attitude that is not acceptable these days. My advice pick annother Hotel

Reviews.Title: “An overpriced relic”
Reviews.Author: zippyfan
Reviews.Content: I thought the hotel was a magnificent piece of history but some things should be confined to the past. The standard of the hotel in relation to the price was poor in comparison to other places I have stayed at in California. I found that the car parking charge was $24 per day. Most hotel parking is free. This was a hidden cost I could have done without. Oh, and it is only valet parking so be careful if you have a rental car. If you want to know where the nearest convenience store is - don't bother asking the receptionist! Overall, it the hotel is clean but a bit of a relic and there is no heart to the place. Service is polite but not necessarily efficient and some staff cannot speak English. It is certainly not a four-star hotel.

Reviews.Title: “not a 4 star”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This hotel is not up to it's 3 or 4 star standard. It should be a 2 star. I will state my case: We checked in and was told that the room we reserved.. a king non-smoking.. was not available. Instead, we had to choose between a queen and a double. Don't be fooled. The room is not luxuriously decorated. It does not match the ornate lobby. It is super tiny. Beds are like Motel 6. No extra nice duvets or covers. Staff may not be paying attention to details.. such as hallway lights gone out. The AC was not working in our room. We complained about the room. The next night, we got our king sized bed and a room twice as big. With it, we had a little sitting area.. yet it just looked underfurnished.. and still w/ the same ugly furniture. You also get a vanity area, yet it's really just.. a cubby w/ a glued on mirror. Parking is expensive.. about 25 a night.

Reviews.Title: “Parking”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Everything about this hotel is fine, but the parking needs to be improved. The receptionists are great, but the hotel charges too much for the parking. Overnight parking is about $30 additional. My friend lived there for 2 days and I left my car there end up spending about $60 for just 2 day parking. They dont have any free parking for the guests either living there or just dropping by for dinner.

Reviews.Title: “A Classic”
Reviews.Author: ackee
Reviews.Content: My wife and I spent three nights at the Biltmore. We heap our praises upon the attentive staff, particularly the personnel in the hotel's dining rooms. They made our stay comfortable and pleasing. While we generally do not favor hotels of the size of the Biltmore -- principally because we think that the service suffers -- we recommend this property for its large rooms (with crown and base mouldings and shutters), spectacular lobby (a wonderful setting for the tea that the hotel offers each afternoon), surprisingly well-equipped gym (next to an Art Deco pool)and atmosphere of grace. We note that downtown LA is not a whirl of activity. But the Biltmore is near the freeway and (even better to our thinking) the Metro and Union Station. Should you wish to get out and explore we suggest taking a train to Pasadena or to Long Beach. Both are short trips and you will skip the SoCal traffic that we dread. When we next visit Los Angeles we will return to the Biltmore.

Reviews.Title: “A Great Experience!”
Reviews.Author: roadtripper081
Reviews.Content: A few friends and I planned a spur of the moment, 4 night trip to Los Angeles. The pictures of the Biltmore looked wonderful and we really liked the location so we made our reservations. I started to get a little worried after reading some reviews about the hotel and I just figured that I would have to find out for myself. I just want to say that my experience was absolutely perfect! Everyone at the hotel, from the concierge to security to the valets and housekeeping, were incredibly friendly and accomodating. We wanted to check out the ballrooms on the lobby level (the Crystal Ballroom is where the Academy Awards used to be held) but some of them were locked. We happened to come across a security guard and just inquired about the history and he offered to take us through the locked ballrooms. The valet service was very convenient and not unreasonable (anyone from a large city would be used to paying for parking). We had a large corner room which had 3 huge windows that faced onto a courtyard - it was bright and extremely quiet, we didn't hear any traffic at all which was nice considering we were staying right in downtown LA. This is a great location, very close to everything...took less than 30 minutes to get to Santa Monica beach on a beautiful Friday afternoon. I would definitely stay here again!

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel with glitchy service”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I did not intend to waste time on writing reviews, but what i read below struck me as probably "commissioned" from the hotel management. It's true that this is a majesticly looking hotel at least at its lobby levels. The downtown location is really convenient and allows for some walk-arounds in the city. (Still late night walks in LA and SF are not recommended as those are laced with homeless people who cluster at dark for their rowdy drinking and may become agressive while panhandling, reminds me of New York in our pre-Giuliani years)The club level rooms are bigger than the standard ones and ours came with breakfast and pre-evening snacks included. The service however varies from friendly to incompetent and downright hostile, depending on whom you get. We stayed 4 nights there over X-mas and came across at many employees asking for different things. We got confusing and contradicting answers like noone was truly aware what hotel's policies were. As in all US hotels the rooms in this one do not have ceiling lights-as one of the floor lamps in our room was missing a bulb I asked and left notes for a replacement for 2 days without much of an effect and ended up bying one for $0.99 from the nearby drugstore. When we left, my 9 year old daughter forgot a toy-cat in the room, we tried to call several times still from CA and got the telephone runaround to a department with a person who was always missing, left 3 or 4 mesages and sent 5 or 6 e-mails without having someone to answer whether at least they've found the toy. I don't even want to remember for the front desk guy who was refusing to let us into our room (with 2 young kids and weary of an 6 hour flight) because I've lost my AAA card (status verification from AAA is possible over the phone or online within 2 or 3 minutes) until someone higher intervened and left that verification issue for a more convenient time. Ah, and also it took them 2 1/2 days and 4 calls on my part to deliver a fax to our room. Yet we met some very helpful staffers during our stay and most of them balanced their poor English with an exuberant good will and after several explanations would finally understand what do you want from them.

Reviews.Title: “I had always wanted to stay here...”
Reviews.Author: Deepsilvr
Reviews.Content: .. and I was not disappointed. This old hotel had always been on my wish list of places to stay. So when the oppurtunity came for me to visit my mother over the Christmas holiday, I knew right where I wanted to stay. From the time I checked in, everyone was very very nice. Please keep in mind I was traveling alone and am a 25 year old woman who looks 18. The took me very seriously and answered all my questions. The only thing I did not like that Expedia did not tell me about when booking the room was that they needed a credit card where they could hold $50 a day for extra room charges (phone calls, room service, etc.) When I explained to the front desk clerk that I did not have that, she happily waived that fee and I had to use the phone in the lobby. I could still receive phone calls in my room for no charge and my cell phone worked just fine on the 4th floor. No problem for me. The location is wonderful. The DASH service gets you almost anywhere downtown for a quarter and drops off right in front of the hotel. Same goes for the bus and underground system, which is about 1 block away. The shopping at Macy's Plaza and the Shops at 7th and Fig. were only blocks away. As for food, the dinning at the hotel was a bit to pricey for me but there are tons of fast food and small places around the area. Not to mention that Domino's pizza delivers to the hotel. The concierge desk was SO helpful with all information that I needed, from places to eat downtown, to museum hours during the holidays, to getting history on the hotel. The room was very comfortable and clean. There was no mini-bar but I was thankful not to have that temptation. I had just a regular room and was very happy with my choice. All in all I would recommend this for anyone. Very pleasent place to stay within a piece of Downtown Los Angeles history.

Reviews.Title: “I Love an Old Hotel”
Reviews.Author: dsikula
Reviews.Content: Just spent a long weekend at the Biltmore. Pluses: Staff was friendly and helpful. Room was surprisingly huge and quiet. Valet parking efficient and quick. The afternoon tea a delight. The gym and indoor pool a time machine. Great for exploring and people-watching. Convenient to everything downtown. Minuses: Nonexistent water pressure in the shower. A lovely view of an airshaft. The price of the valet parking. Overall: I couldn't recommend it more highly, and would definitely stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Service is Questionnable at the Millenium Biltmore...”
Reviews.Author: mini
Reviews.Content: We expected more of the Millenium Biltmore and from the start, they totally and completely missed everything that is important to have a quality hotel. First, we arrived and there were some larger events (its 9:00 p.m.). It took us 30 minutes to even get close to the parking/valet area. Ugh! We then checked in (knowing we had 9:30 p.m. reservations at their restaurant. It is published as being open till 10:00. The desk did call to say we would be late.) We then asked for our bags to be taken to the room so we could go to dinner. No can do - The bell hop said - You must be in the room and we cannot deliver for 15 minutes. We explained our dinner reservations and he said - TOO BAD! He did relent and take them up about 5 minutes later. We then got to the restaurant at 9:40 p.m. Ugh! We were basically blasted by the extremely unfriendly hostess - this lady should get a new job!!! She is one heck of an unpleasant person to deal with and said - You are bad people - You did not call to cancel your reservations - We are closing the restaurant now - We won't seat you. Get out! Ugh! Here we are hotel guests - who have been mistreated by the hotel - and here we are getting yelled at. We then went upstairs to talk to the front desk. Ugh! He suggested a couple of places we could have dinner....he said only a few blocks away. We arrived at 2 of them and they both were closing at 10 p.m. We then asked the last place - Know of any places that stay open. Luckily the Standard does! And the Standard Hotel actually has Great Food and a fun bar area! We then went back to our room. The toilet was broken....we had to wait an hour for it to get fixed. We also found the bathroom extremely "tight" corners. Ugh! For the price, its not worth staying here.... We did find the room service menu to be good and enjoyed the room service Japanese breakfast. Of couse, when we got to use their in room check-out, it too was non functional. It took a bit to get the car to the front door by the valet - (Note: The morning bell hop was wonderful and timely.) But in short----service here! Only if you want to get yelled at; told wrong information; mistreated. (By the way we went to the bar and it stayed open till midnight - no munchies on the menu; and when they did not realize they had customers at the bar, we simply moved on up to the room.

Reviews.Title: “Impressive but dissappointing”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: not worth the money as rooms are definitely not three star. staff are friendly enough and service is alright just not worth the money! getting around isn't as scary as it's made out to be in so many other reviews, as long as you don't walk about too late!! I live in glasgow so no big difference there! don't stay in this hotel because if you're just a tourist it's too far away from everything!!

Reviews.Title: “Good Getaway”
Reviews.Author: omalley62
Reviews.Content: Stayed for Thanksgiving and had the buffet. Enjoyed some of the other hotel bars in the area especially the Standard's Rooftop lounge. Nice old place parking was included in the club rate with a great breakfast bar the following day

Reviews.Title: “Great Weekend At The Biltmore”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Stayed at the Biltmore the weekend of Nov. 19th. My friend and I stayed overnight for a Fresno State/USC football game at the Coliseum. I had seen pictures of this historic hotel and had driven past it before so I thought I'd give it a chance. We opted for a millenium club room, which was a decent size and elegantly appointed. The bathroom was a bit small with hardly any counter space around the pedestal sink. Other than that, the room was fine. Our stay included complimentary drinks, which we took advantage of. I'm not much of a drinker and my martini was a bit strong - the bartender went out of his way to ask if it was ok and offered to water it down a bit, which was a pretty cool thing to offer for a novice drinker like me! We also received a complimentary breakfast brunch which was excellent. My friend and I enjoyed the little perks of a grand hotel - like having a turndown service for the beds at night and a newspaper at the foot of our door in the morning. I sound like a hotel broschure, but what can I say, I enjoyed my stay!

Reviews.Title: “Overall a good experience”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: After reading so many mixed reviews online, my wife and I were a little anxious about staying at the millennium biltmore. While each guest's experience will be different, ours was overall good despite a few problems along the way. We arrived late at night and were assigned a room on the club level (even though we didn't pay extra). We were excited about this perk until we walked into our room and found 2 double beds instead of the king we had requested. We called the front desk and they agreed to move us to the next room. When we moved into the hallway to wait for our key to be delivered, we were greeted by a very unpleasant suprise--we could hear very loud music and other sounds coming from a room on our hall. The walls are apparently very thin! We called the front desk again and they agreed to move us to yet another room. They also sent security up promptly to take care of the noisy guests. Our new room was very clean and nicely decorated (even mints on the pillows). However, don't be suprised by the very small bathroom. The bed was also very comfortable! The front desk and concierge were not very helpful at times, but occasionally provided good assistance. The valet (which is required) was slow and needs more workers. We made the mistake several times of trying to get our car at noon or 5:00 (when business meetings from hotel ballrooms were letting out) and eventually gave up on getting our car because of the long line. Also, be sure to call well in advance of needing your vehicle, or you will be waiting a long time! The hotel is truly a classic beauty in the midst of a dingy downtown area. There is a ton of history (spend some time looking at the pictures of all of the academy awards held on premises) and the historic decor has been well maintained. We always felt very safe and taken care of. The hotel is also conveniently located to many different LA destinations. Despite all of the ups and downs of the stay, my wife and I both agreed that we would stay at the hotel again. It is a reasonably priced classy hotel with a convenient location.

Reviews.Title: “Millennium Biltmore - Beautiful hotel!”
Reviews.Author: NEWLA
Reviews.Content: We have just returned from LA having stayed 5 nights at the Millennium Biltmore. It is a grand hotel -beautiful, spacious & comfortable. We stayed in a standard room and as a treat, decided to upgrade to a club room on our last night. We were happy with both rooms. The standard room is adorned with oil paintings and beautiful furniture - the bed was very comfortable. It has a coffee maker. The club room is of course, bigger and more luxuriously furnished. It does not have a coffee maker but you can request one - I suppose the reason is that club room guests have access to the club lounge and are served complimentary beverages (including alcohol) and snacks from 5 - 8pm. There was no fridge in both rooms but ice is available on various floors. We throughly enjoyed our experience at the Millennium Biltmore. The service was great - we were pleased with the room service, bell service, concierge, front desk and housekeeping. We also enjoyed traditional afternoon tea at the Rendevous Court and were impressed by the spread of delightful sandwiches, tarts and cakes. The prices of food at the Rendevous Court are very reasonable and it has a wonderful ambience, casual yet stylish with a fountain in the centre of the room. We had breakfast at Smeraldi's (another reaturant in the hotel) and the food was great. While we were there, two weddings were held in the ballroom. We had a peek through the entrance of the ballroom while they were getting the ballroom ready and it was just so beautiful!! The hotel is also a short walk to department stores such as Macy's and Robinson May's with a number of cafes and restaurants within its vicinity. As it's located in the financial district, it's in the nicer part of downtown LA. In summary, this is a grand hotel with history - if you enjoy the splendour of grand old buildings, you will love the Millennium Biltmore!

Reviews.Title: “Great Stay with a Surprise!”
Reviews.Author: 4Travelers
Reviews.Content: The Millennium Biltmore Hotel is convienently located in downtown Los Angeles near freeway access, shops, and a plaza across the street. The lobby and public spaces are beautiful, full of classic moldings and decorations. If you like history, you would enjoy staying here! You feel like you are walking back in time as you walk through the halls and lobby. There is even a hall full of photos from the first Academy Awards ceremony held in the ballroom. We had no problems with the people who worked at the hotel, from the check-in clerk to the valet parking attendents. Everyone was nice and friendly to us. Our room, which we booked on Priceline, was upgraded to a suite! What a pleasant surprise! There were four of us, my husband and I and our two young children, so the extra space was a wonderful bonus. The suite was the size of a small apartment, complete with a small entry hall, huge living room and dining room plus wet bar and refrigerator, and a separate spacious bedroom (with 2 double beds) and bathroom. There were two TVs, so the kids could watch their shows on one. The rooms were all clean and nicely furnished. The windows had shutters which blocked out the sunlight in the morning. Our suite was located on a corner, so we could see across the street towards Pershing Plaza and over the roof top of a lower building. We felt very comfortable and safe staying here. I peeked into a standard room, and I can report that a standard room is just as spacious as an average hotel room. The same as the bedroom in our suite. I would not have been disappointed with a standard room at all! And all the reviews that mentioned "no coffee maker"...we had one, maybe it came with the suite. But you can always REQUEST A COFFEEMAKER for FREE--it is stated in the hotel's guest room book. It also includes packets of coffee and paper cups with sip and go lids. Our only complaint about the room was that the water temperature in the bathroom was uneven. This happened a lot with the shower. The water temperature from the sink was ok. Also, it took forever for any hot water to reach us during the "slow" time (Wed & Thurs) in the hotel. Once there were more guests on Friday and Saturday did the hot water come on as soon as we turned it on. I think they need to upgrade the bathrooms, especially the showers! Although we understand that parking space is a premium in downtown LA, or ANYWHERE in LA for that matter, we weren't thrilled about the $24.00 per day valet parking fee. Yes, there are other garages across the street and around the block, but they charge a $6.00 fee for evening entry (between 5pm-12am) and then they charge $2.00 per hour after 12am. The total comes out to be close to $24.00--not much of a savings there. We figured that the money we saved on the hotel room went toward parking, so overall everything evened out at $100 per night. Which is still a great deal for downtown LA with parking included! Overall, we had a great stay and would definitely recommend the Biltmore to anyone!

Reviews.Title: “Great Hotel - Don't believe other reviews!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I have no complaints about this hotel. We saw all the bad reviews - small room, bad service. It worried us at first, but when we saw the hotel we were astounded. Parking is a bit steep - $24 a night (all valet). The room we had (you should book a double bedroom for more space) was as large as a living room. The concierge and bellhops were excellent. When getting into your car, there was always a person there to open the door for you. I would say for a three and a half star hotel this was excellent. No complaints anywhere!

Reviews.Title: “I LOVE LA !”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: i stayed at the Biltmore hotel and love it the first time went the 2 time the room we got i could have laid in that bed and never checked out if the hotel was not sold out i would have the view not the best you could look in someone else room the windows opened but watch out you could fall right out of them ok the homeless now i will have to say in los angles there every where i mean it that's los angles bi--g problem however i have walk outside at night no one bothered me yes they begged for money but a stern no works every time and i am a women with my mother looking like we come from the farm the bus driver some are very nice some don't need to be driving there so rude now back to the homeless / skid row i have walk throw it holding my own no on bothered me and my mother with diamonds big ones however it you are scared to death of skid row take a cab sunset bld way over done to much money Santa Monica yes good place to relax bring your wallet homeless there to but not to many Venice beach from Santa Monica its the poor part i feel what i saw china town now there i did not see the homeless but i really was not looking i was looking for food and saw most restaurants where b c if you see a f on the door run for you life ! Japan town i have had so many bad experiences i will not return to any hotel or restaurants long beach its a step up from los angles if i did not want to do la i would do long beach the beach towns are fun the far you go the better it is and the less of the homeless you see if any now back down to la Clifton's buffet look i stop eating there when i saw a homeless man spit on the floor where people ate at in the day los angles is alive the best city but at night around when the shops close is when you see the real los angels the boulevard of broken dreams some are in there right mind some have lost it never the less i love los angles o one more thing the spa at the Biltmore i love it ! and when i go to downtown los angles i will stay there my next stop palm spring !

Reviews.Title: “The Biltmore is the Best”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I found really cheap rates at the Biltmore on their website and decided it would be a great way to kick off my Southern California honeymoon. After I made reservations, I went on Trip Advisor and got really scared by the horrible reports. I thought about trying to get out of my reservation, but figured we would give it a try. We arrived in downtown L.A. and pulled right into the Biltmore's valet parking. Its true that it costs 24 dollars a day, but we drove around and around and that is about what it costs to park yourself in a garage anywhere near downtown, so we didn't feel too bad about forking over the money. The valet service was really lovely: the guys were really nice and prompt. The lobby and bar at the Biltmore is really incredible. We spent a good half an hour just wondering around and feeling very LA. I loved our room. It was a corner room near the top and had a great view of downtown and a little park. The bathroom was also really nice with a big window. There were two paintings on the wall and they were exactly the same. We got a kick out of this. All in all, it was a really cool, elegant, old hotel and while the TV wasn't huge, it was really full of charm and romance.

Reviews.Title: “Poor service, awful rooms”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We stayed there three nights. Was a tremendous experience: the rooms are small and dark, the toilet stinks. The receptionists are rude and the room service is poor. The neighborhood are similar to a skid row and at night I recommend to stay in your room... The good fact is that the building is beautiful.

Reviews.Title: “Service Stinks”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Absolutely love the beautiful public areas of such an historic hotel but the staff needs to get the chip off their shoulder or the management needs to treat them nicer. The front door when arriving was swamped with people and very little guidance. The bellboys were all huddled together. The front desk had a lot of people doing nothing but staring. The room was extremely disappointing worst bed ive ever experienced. The restaurant, Smeraldi's was good. Area is what you should expect from a Downtown hotel so expect many homeless. Good experiences at this hotel? The nice courteous lady in the reservation area who sent me info on the area. The very nice housemaid who made our room as comfortable as could be under the circumstances. Our waiter, "T" at Smeraldi's. The coffee in the morning was good. Save your money or spend more money and stay elsewhere and go to Bitlmore to enjoy the history.

Reviews.Title: “Not as bad as I expected, and yet not a true 4 star hotel either”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We pricelined this hotel for two rooms/ two nights in July 2005. After reading the reviews on this board, I was horrified. However, it wasn't as bad as I expected. Yes, there are a number of homeless/ panhandlers in the general area and if you walk anywhere in downtown LA you will be asked for money. My daughter and I walked during the day and felt safe enough. At night, it was a different story... The hotel staff was more helpful than we expected, especially the concierges. Paying for valet parking can be avoided by parking in one of the many parking garages in the area. The public areas of the hotel are beautiful. The rooms themselves are small and somewhat tired. Also, something to keep in mind: There are virtually no restaurants within walking distance open on weekends. All in all, it was much like staying in the inner cities in Europe and we worried needlessly.

Reviews.Title: “Not to confuse anyone, but...”
Reviews.Author: Rosskel
Reviews.Content: My girlfriend and I spent two nights at the Biltmore and thought it was a very beautiful hotel whose staff were generally pleasant. The only person who was rude to us was the doorman after checking out....but the same guy had been perfectly pleasant to us on the way in! I can only assume the hotel treats it's staff terribly, as the level of service seems to vary wildly. The area around the hotel IS a bit dodgy, but it's generally safe in the daytime. Besides, you'll need a car to get to all the interesting stuff anyway. The pool is very, very nice. Roman baths-style decor. The bar is great, expensive, but great. Speak to the concierge about the various ghosts in the hotel!

Reviews.Title: “Miserable service !!!”
Reviews.Author: MMakosch
Reviews.Content: I can only agree with the latest reviews regarding the miserable service and the way the staff is treating paying guests ! Upon check in they didn't offer any assistance with luggage - although about 10 bored employees waited at the entrance... When asking for assistance with my parcels (I simply wanted to handover my parcel to an UPS driver) I was directed from the concierge to the business center, then to the bellman and finally to the receptionist, who was looking at me as he had never seen a parcel before ! Do these people care at all about how they represent the hotel and the impression they leave people? What an old beautiful hotel with such a rich history and what a lousy service ! Apart from the service, I couldnÂ´t complain about anything else. The room (at least the one we were staying at) was very spacious and clean and they have nice dining possibilities and a good bar with gorgeous Apple Martinis ! Just an advise for all first time and German visitors to LA: this hotel is "hours" away from the real attractions (you wonÂ´t be interested in visiting a museum during your first visit) but if you are still planning to stay at the Biltmore, book with German travel agencies - they have real good bargains compared to the official price list (we payed only about 110 â‚¬ for a night)

Reviews.Title: “This place was nothing like it looked on the website!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: "I was extremely disappointed with the level of service at The Millennium Biltmore Hotel. The toilet and the bathroom floor appeared to be very filthy. It looked like they didn't clean the restroom from the prior guest. Upon check in they didn't offer any assistance with luggage, or inform us of any amenities the hotel had to offer. Over all, the hotel appeared gloomy, nothing like the website portrayed, kind of like the hotel in the movie "the Shining" but worse. The room was dark, and I didn't feel like the sheets and bedding were very clean. My friends and I stayed for two nights at this hotel. When we checked out of the hotel a friend noticed that she left a garment bag hanging in the closet. We called lost in found the less than 24 hours only to talk to the VM and to leave several messages before we were able to speak to some one live. The supervisor stated that there was nothing left in the room we were in and to call back. After several attempts with calling and back and forth conversations with different staff members the items were found after my friend suggested to get a lawyer involved. Within that same day they magically located the missing garment bag, and asked us to pay for shipping. Basically we were given the run around with trying to obtain the items that were accidentally left. I really do not recommend this hotel when visiting LA!!!!! People, you are better off booking a room at the Motel 6 and saving $210.98 for two days.

Reviews.Title: “My Goodness, what an utter let-down...”
Reviews.Author: Lover-not-a-Fighter
Reviews.Content: This hotel was a HUGE disappointment. I booked the hotel about two months in advance for three nights, the first of which was a Universal Studios package (breakfast, Uni Studios tickets and valet parking), the other two the weekend package which included the valet parking. The rates were very admittedly good and unlike one of the reviews I read, the hotel was actually extremely easy to find using google map directions to aide me however upon arriving at the hotel we had to wait for 20 minutes to get into the valet parking area (granted they were having a prom that night). Once we got into the reception area (beautiful but quite empty looking - could use a decorator) we were greeted (and I use that word with a grain of salt) at the check-in counter by a very rude young man who made me feel quite uncomfortable. We got up to our room which was very pretty indeed - until I went into the bathroom where there was a reddish sort of stain on the bathtub and the fixtures were so dirty they looked as though they'd never been cleaned and until I saw the view - we were also on a 'club floor' but with a distressing view of the back of the other building. We waited for our luggage to arrive as we were wanting to go out that evening and needed to change but the time ticked on and on and still no luggage. I also realized that we weren't given our Universal Studios tickets when we checked in nor was there a hotel directory (with room service menu etc) in the room so I called the bellhop to find out where our luggage might be. I was asked by the lady if we had asked for our luggage to be brought up (umm-yup?) to which I of course replied yes, we asked the valet to send it up and even told him exactly which bags were needed. After putting me on hold for an interminable length of time she came back on the phone to say we didn't know you wanted it brought in (umm that's interesting since we were on record with reservations for three days so not really sure what we would do without our luggage which was in plain view in the car!!) and would I like directions to my car so I could go and get it? No exaggeration. Well, I've never been asked this before and was more than a little dumbfounded but after gathering my wits I nicely said no I was under the impression the bellhop would be bringing it up. She then transferred me to the bellhop who shockingly also asked if I would like to come down and get it!! To put this into perspective, my 11 yr old daughter and I were on a three week roadtrip, we had two large suitcases, one smaller suitcase, one laptop, one large toiletries bag and other sundry bags which we carried in ourselves so this was not a manageable amount of luggage for me to go and "pick up" from the lobby. Anyway, they eventually brought it up but let me tell you it was hard to give the guy a tip (even though of course none of it was his fault). I then phoned the front desk to ask about the Uni Studios tickets which they questioned me on saying they had been given to me at check-in which I was again surprised to hear (I guess they didn't believe me?) I told her they had not been given to me which I should think would easily enough be checked. I was again put on hold for ages and when she finally came back she tersely said she'd send them up. I then had to ask her about the hotel directory which she said was a housekeeping issue and that I'd have to speak with them about it at which point she then transferred me although I half expected her to hang up so I'd have to phone them myself. I spoke to housekeeping who were very nice. Our luggage still had not arrived, in fact when it eventually DID arrive it had taken an hour and fifteen minutes. By this time it was too late for us to make our dinner reservations in West Hollywood that I'd had for a month so we had little choice but to order from the room service menu and unlike the person from Nebraska who commented that the prices were reasonable (omg - $16 for a hamburger is not what I call reasonable) I must heartily disagree with them and believe me, I'm not the most budget-minded person by any stretch of the imagination. The bill came...$36 for 1 hamburger, 1 tiny half bottle of 7-Up and 1 piece of apple pie with ice cream which included (although I was not informed about this) the gratuity (I added tip to make the total $40) and taxes. When I phoned a day later to ask why the bill was so high they then told me the gratuity was already added and said they'd refund my $4 tip! - this was not in fact done not that it would have made a difference anyway) Quite unbelievable. I very badly wanted to complain about the whole experience but thought I'd wait another night and see how things went. I didn't end up complaining though I truly wish I had done but only because the person who checked us out was so rude and made me feel so uncomfortable that I felt terribly intimidated - he didn't even ask how our stay was (that would have been the point where I would have said something) or whether everything was to our liking - questions which I have come to expect from the calibre of the hotels I stay in. This all says nothing about the surrounding area which is INDEED slummy looking. The area coming from the north from the highway to the hotel is fine (Mus of Metropolitan Art, etc) but the area an immediate block south and all around from there becomes highly unsafe looking and feeling. I had to advise my daughter not to look at anyone as we were driving by, the area IS ugly and scary looking. Your member from Canoga Park who said the area is NOT unsafe is kidding themselves, when he says "further east of the hotel" he must mean by further, a block, east, west and south as well and I would under no circumstances walk around with my daughter in the area surrounding the hotel, in fact I wouldn't chance it with a male adult either. I will never stay in this hotel again unless they were to take some serious instruction in customer service and the art of dealing with people effectively. Do these people care at all about how they represent the hotel and the impression they leave people? Apparently not but the hotel management should be advised that this is the downfall of the hotel and a probable reason why they get little repeat business. The hotel's architecture is so very, very beautiful and it's history so steeped in tradition that it's a very big shame it should be ruined by the lacking service of many of it's front-line staff. Shame on this hotel and shame on many of it's employees - a HUGE disappointment.

Reviews.Title: “You'll never leave the Hotel”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I stayed here for five nights in the begining of June. This place is Teir 1. The valet parking is easy and fast. The lobby is great, it is all marble and has beautiful furnishings everywhere. The rooms are very comfortable and good sized. The Sushi bar is fantastic and they also have a Mediterranian restaurant that is ok. The pool is very nice and they have all the cardio and weights you can ask for. This is were they used to hold the Academy Awards and they have weddings here all the time. This just brings a happy atmosphere to the hotel. The only reason I didn,y give it an excellent is because there are the typical pan handlers and you shouldn't walk outside at night alone.

Reviews.Title: “I love the Biltmore & downtown LA”
Reviews.Author: Out_of_valley
Reviews.Content: I have stayed at the Biltmore several times over the past few years and have always loved it. The area of downtown LA where the Biltmore is located is NOT dangerous and is NOT near skid row, which is further east. Yes, there is the occasional panhandler, but that is a minor nuisance. There is a lot to see and do downtown - Museum of Contemporary Art, Disney Hall concerts, etc. The hotel itself is beautiful; the murals in the lounge next to the bar should not be missed. I have eaten at Sai-Sai, the Japanese restaurant in the hotel, many times - excellent. The rooms are charming and many have a view.

Reviews.Title: “Not a pleasant experience”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I would not recommend this hotel to my worst enemy. This hotel is the thing that nightmares are made of. The location is terrible - it is located in a dangerous part of town and incredibly hard to find. The beauty of the hotel itself ends in the lobby - the rooms are small and not clean, the staff is rude and unbearable, and the hotel itself has a bad smell to it. Instead of treating their guests as paying customers and in a friendly and helpful way - the employees at this hotel treat their guests as though they should not have any requests or questions and should stay out of their way. The staff is pretentious and does not make their guests feel welcome. This hotel is not worth the price. I will never return to this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Things not always better the second time around”
Reviews.Author: 1happydisneygirl
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at this hotel in 2001 and had such a wonderful time, we promised ourselves we would go back. Well, we wish we hadn't kept our promise! When we arrived, the front desk peronnel wasn't as friendly as the last time. In fact, they weren't helpful at all. It was the bellhop who was sooooooooo nice. Without asking, he told us everything about LA and what we could do and where we could go. He also told us about the hotel amenities. He was very informative. We stayed on the 10th floor, which is the Club Level. We were told at check in that the rooms had been renovated and we would be very happy with ours. Oh my. If our room had been renovated, I would hate to see the rest. The 10th floor smelled old and musty. Our room and bathroom were dirty. The walls looked patched up and the shower head was disgusting and looked like it hadn't been cleaned since it was first installed. When I sat on the bed, it felt hard as a rock, so I called down to housekeeping to ask for a bed pad. The lady told me she didn't think they had pads and I should call the front desk and ask to be moved since most of the mattresses had been replaced in the last year, but our mattress was one of the ones that hadn't. So, I called down to front desk who said they would check on it for me. When front desk called back, she rudely informed me the mattresses on our floor hadn't been replaced and there was nothing she could do. She said she would send housekeeping up to put a pad on the bed. They did, but I had to jump thru hoops to get it. Because we stayed on the club level, we had evening "snacks" and continental breakfast. WOW!!! That was definitely worth the upgrade. The breakfast was delicious and plentiful, with fresh pastries, scrambled eggs, bacon, sausage, fresh oj and the freshest/sweetest mix of berries I've ever eaten. We ate at Sai Sai, the on-site Japanese restaurant. We had eaten there before and had a wonderful experience. Not so this time. The waitress handed us our menus and returned about 3 minutes later (no exaggeration) and asked us if we had made up our minds. When we told her we needed more time, she became irritated. She hovered over us (without being helpful) the whole time and we felt like we shouldn't be there. It was very uncomfortable. And then our food arrived cold. The 10th floor concierge was definitely much more helpful and friendly than the lobby staff. The gentleman manning the concierge desk spent a considerable amount of time showing us maps of LA and telling us where to go and where to eat. We followed most of his suggestions and weren't disappointed. Check out was a different story. The valet staff must have been in a bad mood because they were rude to everyone. People were complaining to management and staff. It was sad. I'm not sure what happened at this hotel in the last few years, but our stay at the Biltmore was a big disappointment for us and we won't be back. I've stayed at some "old" hotels that have updated their facilities without losing their historical charm. Unfortunately, the Biltmore isn't one of those places. I also hope the front desk and valet staff remembers that they represent the hotel and should seek some friendly advice from the bellhops.

Reviews.Title: “The best choice in downtown LA - one of the best in the region”
Reviews.Author: dalangdon
Reviews.Content: The Millenium Biltmore is a classic hotel with excellent service and beautiful atmosphere. The guest rooms are immaculate and tastefully appointed, the restaurants superb and the architecture of this hotel make it both a landmark and local treasure. It excludes the glamour and elegance of a bygone era, a Los Angeles that is almost extinct. Very few hotels in the LA area have the history and ambiance of the Biltmore, and it is definitely worth a visit. While downtown LA is not as vibrant as other cities, the Biltmore is within easy walking (yes, walking - in LA!) distance of the major corporate, cultural and tourist sites - and if you don't want to walk, cabs and limos are easily obtained from the staff. The Biltmore is a must-do experience in Los Angeles.

Reviews.Title: “One of the best we've been too!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Biltmore while on vacation in Los Angeles. We were extremely impressed with the hotel. We found a great deal for the Biltmore online for $140 a night. This included FREE valet parking, complimentary continental breakfast and hor' dourves and beer and wine in the evening. In addition, this price included an upgrade to the club rooms which are located on the eleventh and twelfth floor of the building. The club rooms are supposedly bigger and offer more services than standard rooms. I wouldn't know because I don't know what a standard room includes. The continental breakfast was great. It included lots of fresh fruit, danishes, croissants, cereal, and two hot dishes. One hot dish was always scrambled eggs (which were very good) and either sausages or bacon for the second dish. Food never ran out. Dinner included two hot hor' dourves dishes, complimentary wine and beer, cheese and cracker dish, fresh fruit and cookies. The food was great and on a few nights, we made it our dinner. Once again, food and drinks never ran out. There was always a concierge and waitress on hand to make sure we were well taken care of during meals. Meals were held in the club lounge which was spacious and had tables, telvisions, and couches. It looked like a big living room. There was also a computer room and fax machine that we had access to during meals. The valet service was extremely convenient and thankfully free(it was part of my package). When you are in Los Angeles, the only way to go is to park in a lot and they all charge. The room was beautiful and the bed was SO comfortable. The staff were extremely friendly and accomodating. We were originally concerned that we would be staying in downtown L.A. which is like a ghost town at night and even during the day (compared to NYC). However, it wasn't a big deal because no matter what, you need to drive everywhere to see attractions. The biltmore is not much more out of the way compared to other locations. I highly recommend this hotel and would return without reservation.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful architecture, slow service”
Reviews.Author: ladyt
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Biltmore while attending a conference. The architecture of the hotel is beautiful. The room was adequate and the bed comfortable. The housekeeping staff was reponsive and efficient. Unfortunately, the banquet staff was a bit slow in the upkeep of the meeting rooms (e.g. removing debris from tablecloths or changing soiled tablecloths). I was surprised that the escalator to the Biltmore Bowl was often inoperative when my group was going to convene in the room. I would think twice about staying at this hotel in the future.

Reviews.Title: “We loved the Biltmore!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: The Biltmore was our final stay on a bus tour with 29 people. We all had very comfortable rooms (no complaints) and the hotel itself is truly beautiful...there are photos showing the grand events that took place back in Hollywood's "glory days" and we all enjoyed viewing the big stars of the day...it used to host the Acadamy Awards. The intricate detail of the ceilings and walls is amazing and a true historical treasure...no complaints about the 100 year old elevators because they just add to the hotel's authentic character. Yes, the rooms are not as large as newer hotels, but people need to appreciate this hotel for its beautiful architecture and history (believe me, we are not history buffs but could not help but appreciate the splendor of this hotel). The staff that we dealt with were very professional and we highly recommend this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Better than expected”
Reviews.Author: WilfFrance
Reviews.Content: Having read a few reviews after I had booked this hotel that were not very encouraging, it was with some apprehension that my wife and me checked in here in March 2005. All of these fears soon dissapeared as we took in the surroundings and the rooms which are first class. Sure there were a few mini hiccups like the TV system which was undergoing a changeover of some sort but we didn't travel to LA to watch TV! The car parking is a bit of a rip off but again, this is LA and at least the car parking ervice is efficient and takes away the problem of doing it yourself and finding the wheels missing next day. If you need somewhere sumptuous to stay over, this is the place. However, remember this is downtown with not much to see in the area if you're walking. Oh, and the Water Grill restaurant adjacent to the hotel. Its good, but take a mortgage out for the bill. With the wine list starting in the region of $80/100 plus for the local brew you can make your own mind up!

Reviews.Title: “HORRIBLE SERVICE”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the hotel for a wedding. Prior to our arrival, I called and confirmed our reservation for a non-smoking king size bed. When we got to the hotel, they stated they only had two non-smoking rooms - queen size and double size beds. So we opted for the non-smoking/queen size bed. The room was small, old, smelley, dusty and the lights were not working. Our request for the second room was met with rude commentary and poor service. The second was much better than the first room, but more in-line with a one or two star hotel. It was not a four-star hotel. Other guests that were attending the wedding also stayed at the hotel and had similar experiences. We were all very disappointed with the cleanliness of the rooms, service at the front desk and valet. We would NOT stay there again.
